analytic.title: An Evolutionary Theory of Values

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Thanks to Anat Bardi, Royal Holloway University of London for initial guidance and for facilitating the research described in the supplementary materials. Thanks also to Shalom Schwartz for encouragement, guidance and for introducing Anat Bardi.

div.p: system of values An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials) As we will demonstrate, the temporal stability of all systems, from the earliest formed, simplest atoms onwards, is dependent on the cooperation of their components. We locate such systems in the conservative/cooperative quadrant of a universal motivational map (UMM) with a structure equivalent to that of Schwartz's system. In the anthropocentric terminology of the ten personal values 1 of system, this is equivalent to the 'traditions' of all stable systems being dependent on the mutual 'benevolence' of their components. Sustainable internalized motivations for competition and change only emerged in the evolution of the complex adaptive systems of organisms. Of organismic systems, only that of the human mind would appear capable of generating change based on cooperative motivations associated with near universal, conscious appreciations of the greater systems of which it is part.

We consider the possibility that if human values evolved sequentially as components of an increasingly sophisticated decision-making mechanism, they may still exert a hierarchical pattern of influence on human cognition and decision-making. Comparing individual responses to a selection of decision-making tasks with corresponding personal values profiles, we present experimental evidence that suggest they do. Since we are not aware of any competing theory that would predict this, the plausible explanation we provide for these otherwise unexpected findings invites further investigation.

div.head: Theory in psychology
div.p: Borghi and Fini (2019) identify a lack of emphasis on theoretical contributions as a deficiency of modern psychological science. While acknowledging the importance of empirical investigation, they point out that without a broad-based theoretical framework, core principles that accelerate scientific progress are likely to be missed. Specifically, they state "complex phenomena such as mental and cognitive processes can be understood only starting from multiple perspectives" (Borghi & Fini, 2019, p.1), and "prioritizing empirical results over theory can instead lead to a growing tendency to obtain fragmented and conflicting evidence about a phenomenon" (Borghi & Fini, 2019, p2).

Theories may be judged by the degree of informed consensus surrounding them. This tends to decrease as one moves up the hierarchy of sciences (Comte, 1854): from fundamental mathematics and physics, through the increasingly complex sciences of chemistry and biology, to the social sciences and psychology (Fanelli & Glanzel, 2013). Whatever the theoretical challenges of maths and physics, they are as nothing compared to those facing psychologists. Whereas the widely accepted theories of physics concern just 12 fundamental building blocks of nature and 4 forces (Fermilab, 2014), psychologists are tasked with making sense of the outputs of an unimaginably complex set of interactions between approximately 60 trillion neural network connections (e.g., Gulati, 2015).

The five-factor model, whether in its appended HEXACO form or not, is arguably one the best established in psychology, and the most widely adopted in the study of personality. Yet Block (2010) criticised it for being atheoretical; falling short because it is incomplete, non-systematic, and simply descriptive. He said that what is needed is "an adaptive paradigm … a model or point of view or productive principles that can, in Gell-Mann's memorable and guiding phrase, generate sufficient 'surface complexity arising out of deep simplicity'" (Block, 2010, p.22). He echoed McAdams & Pals (2006, p. 204) statement that the aim for the study of personality is "to provide an integrative framework for understanding the whole person" (Block, 2010, p.19). Also saying "It is about time we recognized that heredity and environment are not simply additively related; their connection is complex and nonlinear, often synergistic" (Block, 2010, p.5).

We argue that the values model replicates a motivational structure that delivers on all of Block's (2010) aspirations. It is systematic, complete, and, when considered in relation to fundamental principles and insights from physics, evolution by natural selection, and complexity theory, offers a simple, unifying perspective from which to explain all human psychological and social phenomena. Gell-Mann (1994) himself observed that traversing the layers of complexity between the fundamental mechanisms of physics and the high-level emergent phenomena of psychology requires computations of intractable complexity. However, he believed similarities among systems at different levels point toward connections between the fundamental and the emergent that could be used to approach a deeper understanding.

Evolution in this universe has been driven by the same fundamental motivational forces in accordance with the same physical laws for some 13.8 billion years (Kolb, 1990;Planck Collaboration, 2020). Countless, increasingly complex systems have emerged over this period. Of these, humanity, in the form of homo sapiens, emerged around 200-300,000 years ago (Brooks et al., 2018;Marean et al., 2007): i.e., in the last forty-sixth-thousandth of this period. Yet, even evolutionary-and comparative-psychologists tend not to look beyond it when trying to build a clearer picture of why we are as we are (e.g., Bryer et al., 2020). That the psychological phenomenon of personality has been attributed to organisms as simple as bacteria , which evolved three billion years ago (Alegado & King, 2019), should draw attention to the possibility that such anthropocentric myopia may have inhibited our ability to achieve a deeper understanding.

In the following we traverse a vast scientific terrain: from quantum physics to social psychology through classical physics, chemistry, and evolutionary biology. In the interests of brevity and making the argument comprehensible to psychologists who may be unfamiliar with much of this terrain, we have endeavoured to offer explanations in the simplest possible terms while remaining true to the underlying science. The principles described are universal and apply at every layer of evolving complexity. Their simplicity contrasts with the numerous, complex, and diverse emergent mechanisms for which they are responsible. While examples of these are provided, they are intended as way-markers rather than contiguous steppingstones by which to traverse the terrain.

div.head: An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials)
div.p: Aside from considerations of brevity, when describing the evolution of complex systems, analysis of such detail is considered counter-productive, since the computations required to fully account for the evolutionary process are intractable (e.g., Axelrod 1997;Gell-Mann, 1994;Holland, 1995). Of greater interest are repetitive patterns that emerge at different levels of complexity, as these provide our best clues as to the universality of the underlying mechanisms.

The theory we advance has been developed from a transdisciplinary perspective. It is anchored in fundamental and universal principles, linked to the structure of values model. It is not based on other psychological theories. Accordingly, we have neither reviewed nor extensively referred to examples of these in the main text. We provide commentary on relationships with prominent theories and models that may be of interest in the supplementary materials. Our evolutionary theory offers the potential to contextualise all such theories within a parsimonious framework.

div.head: Core principles relevant to the evolution of the universe, and hence human psychology
div.p: It is beyond the scope of this article to fully describe the theories and well-established principles that drive the evolution of natural systems. In the supplementary materials (SM1) we provide brief descriptions and citations relating to selected core principles, namely: quantum uncertainty, the structure of atoms, gravitational and electromagnetic fields, the first and second laws of thermodynamics, energy transfer between systems, and evolution by natural selection. From these it follows that: (a) even the simplest, most stable atoms (from which all matter is made) are fundamentally dynamic systems; (b) all things in the universe are systematically connected such that they contribute to each other's environment, their influence on each other increasing exponentially with proximity, with gravity tending to draw systems together so they become entwined; (c) since energy cannot be destroyed or created, gains and losses to and from local systems must be compensated for in external systems -localised increases in order come at the expense of delocalised disorder; (d) all systems tend toward energetic equilibrium, with their components An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials) displacing each other, so releasing kinetic energy (in the form of photons) to minimize their total potential energy (TPE); (e) since the electrons in atomic systems may only emit and absorb photons with energy levels particular to each atomic element, streams of photons pass between atomic systems, effectively transmitting information that is perceived and processed differently by different atomic systems; (f) systems (including organisms) evolve through a winnowing process akin to survival of the fittest, where fitness is derived from a system's ability to process (dissipate) energy more efficiently than competing systems in the context of its environment (England, 2015), so accelerating entropy (disorder) globally in accordance with the second law of thermodynamics (Kaila & Annila, 2008). Accordingly, the human brain may be considered a consequence of 13.8 billion years of evolution by natural selection producing increasingly complex and energy-efficient processing systems.

div.head: Complexity and complex adaptive systems.
div.p: The Schrodinger (1926) equation, which describes the wave functions 2 of quantum particles and their environmental interactions, represents a fundamental building block of quantum mechanical theory. Hence it may be regarded as key to explaining the existence and operation of all things in the universe. It can be used to accurately predict the permitted electron energy orbitals of atomic elements, and so their chemical properties. Armed with this and other equations and insights from quantum mechanics, one might consider it possible to accurately predict the behavior of all things from the behavior of their fundamental components. However, while the laws of physics enable us to predict the interactions of dynamic systems comprising just two bodies, the introduction of just a third gives rise to complex interactions that render systems chaotic and unpredictable, in the long term at least (Gowers et al., 2008). Poincare's proof of this in 1890 led to the development of chaos theory (Letellier et al., 2021), of which the butterfly effect (Lorenz, 1963) is possibly the best-known concept. This describes how very small changes in one part of a complex system may have very large Holland (1995) describes fitness as context dependent. Dawkins ( , 1982 considers this at multiple levels of complexity: from the context of a gene within a chromosome, to the context of a cell within an organ, to the context of organisms within an environment of overlapping extended phenotypes, to the context of memes within a culture. Dawkins (1982) introduced the concept of the extended phenotype to include all the effects of a gene: i.e., those beyond physiology and behavioral traits. Termite mounds, spider's webs, and beaver dams are among the examples of physical structures that are as much consequences of gene-environment interactions as the physical and neurological traits facilitating their construction. The construction of dam lakes by beavers directly affects the environments of other organisms, so setting in motion a chain of complex interactions. In the case of humanity, where the actions of one individual can affect a world population of 8 billion (Dion, 2022), the potential for interacting extended phenotypes to trigger synchronized responses across the CAS of life on Earth is all too apparent. Because all things contribute to the environment of all other things, the interaction of extended phenotypes and other environmental interactions may generate feedback loops that contribute to reciprocal causations of evolution. The effects of these may be experienced at all levels of complexity, from the interaction of complex molecules in self-catalytic processes of the RNA world from which life may have emerged Rich, 1965) upwards. Hunter (2008) stresses the importance of Dawkins' (1982) idea of extended phenotypes in the development of the current extended evolutionary synthesis of Darwin's (1859) original theory of evolution.
The principles of natural selection are traditionally applied to biological evolution via reproduction.

However, just as organisms evolved from non-living complex molecules (e.g., Böttcher, 2018), the principles underlying evolution by natural selection pre-date the emergence of life. Pross (2005) considers fitness and natural selection to be representations of more fundamental concepts. Indeed, Dawkins (1989, p.12) suggested that 'survival of the fittest' might be reconsidered as a special case of 'survival of the most stable'. An equivalent of which may be used to explain the abundance of free stable atoms such as those of carbon and gold, and free molecules of water, oxygen, and cellulose, at the expense of more reactive (less stable) free atoms of potassium, sodium, and lithium. So, while potassium atoms are of themselves considered stable, and potassium is the eighth most abundant element in the Earth's crust, its susceptibility to reacting with Earth's abundant oxygen and water molecules ensures its atoms never occur in their free form (Emsley, 2010).

Chemical reactions leading to the survival of the most stable tend to be settled relatively quickly, as atomic and molecular systems reconfigure into more energy-efficient states of equilibrium. By contrast, the fitness of organisms can only be determined over many generations. Rather than evolve through single interactions between stable states, organisms retain coherence by maintaining far-from-equilibrium states (Prignone & Nicolis, 1985) by continually absorbing and dissipating energy. Inanimate CAS, such as sand dunes and hurricanes, maintain far-from-equilibrium states by passively absorbing energy from their environment, whereas organisms actively orchestrate its acquisition.

div.head: Cooperation and competition
div.p: Consistent with quantum uncertainty , all stable systems in equilibrium are fundamentally dynamic, in that their constituent particles can never be at rest. Accordingly, their constituents cooperate to maintain system stability: literally, work together to the same end (Oxford Dictionaries, 2023). The scientific definition of work is to transfer energy. In a stable system that has minimized its TPE, such as an atom, energy may be transferred between components but must be conserved overall (Moskowitz, 2014). Systems become unstable when disequilibrium causes the displacement of components as they move to minimize their TPE, radiating kinetic energy as they do so.

In an ecological context, competition concerns interactions involved in attempting to gain a share of a limited resource (Oxford Dictionaries, 2023). In the context of physical systems, this limited resource is their minimum TPE. This is subject to localised environmental constraints. For example, while most atoms are stable in most environments, in high energy environments, such as those encountered in stars and supernovas, they may become unstable. In these environments lower minima of TPE become possible. Iron and Nickel atoms have the most energy-efficient, tightly bound nuclei, and so are the most stable atomic systems (Fewell, 1995). Given the abundance of elements in the universe tends to decline with mass, the relatively high abundance of iron and nickel in the solar system (Arnett, 1995) would appear to be an example of Dawkin's (1989) preferential 'survival of the most stable'.

Cooperation and competition are opposing factors in evolution, yet, due to the first law of thermodynamics, and the fact that systems can only be in equilibrium or not, they are also complementary. Their importance in evolution by natural selection, the functioning of organisms, and, more generally, in the study of CAS is widely acknowledged (Axelrod, 1997;Bovaird 2008;Holland, 1995;Nowak & Highfield, 2012). The model most frequently refenced to illustrate the relationship between them (see Kaufmann, 1995;Nowak & Highfield, 2012) is game theory's The Prisoner's Dilemma, developed by Flood and Drechsler at the RAND corporation (Poundstone, 1993). Its wide-ranging utility may be appreciated by relating its basic premise and scoring system to energetic interactions between physical systems. In the game two players are faced with an identical binary choice: whether to seek to maximise their personal benefit at the cost of the other (defect/compete) or refuse to do so, preferring to share the same fate (cooperate). Each makes their decision without knowledge of what the other will do, yet their outcomes are co-dependent on these decisions. These can be scored as shown in fig. 2.

div.head: Fig. 2 The Prisoner's Dilemma scoring matrix
div.p: Axelrod & Hamilton (1981) staged a competition for research purposes in which game theorists in economics, sociology, political science, and mathematics were invited to submit strategies for playing an iterated version of The Prisoners Dilemma. No limits were placed on the complexity or simplicity of the strategies. The winning strategy -'tit for tat' -was simple: to cooperate first and then, in all subsequent rounds, repeat what the other player did in the previous round. If both players cooperate, they maximise their joint returns. If the other player defects they will be punished for doing so in the next round. The strategy of 'always defect' may be considered rational, since it ensures a player cannot come off worse than their opponent and offers the potential of maximizing one's relative gain. 'Always defect' is considered an evolutionary stable strategy because it cannot be beaten by a single mutated alternative (Cowde,, 2012). However, when played by two rational players it is highly unlikely the other party will choose to continue cooperating, taking the 'sucker's payoff' (Axelrod & Hamilton, 1981) of 0 points while ceding 5 points to the other player. Accordingly, it is more likely they will get stuck with 1 point each. Evolution by natural selection may not be rational, but through extensive trial and error it tends toward optimal solutions. A version of Holland's genetic algorithm, when presented with the same challenge, arrived at an improved version of tit for tat by allowing for the possibility of bluffing one's opponent (Axelrod, 1987).

If points are taken to represent energy, a meeting of cooperative strategies maximises energy conservation by the conjoined physical system of the two 'players', whereas competitive encounters involve much loss of energy. For example, two oxygen atoms combine to form molecular oxygen with little loss of energy, whereas reactions between potassium and water are violent: resulting in much energy loss through physical movement, heat, and light. Given that, in nature, systems may retain and accrue energy so that 'points' accumulate between 'rounds of play', not only does cooperation maximise energy-efficiency it also has the potential to allow systems to gain power relative to those 'playing by' other strategies, and so outcompete them. In the case of organisms subject to competition from resistant prey, hostile predators, bacteria, viruses, etc., this gives them greater potential to sustain damage and prevail. In the case of human systems, organizations in which individuals cooperate may more efficiently direct their energies to corporate endeavour than those in which energy is consumed in internal competition (e.g., Deery & Iverson, 2005;Spurny et al., 2022).

The evolution of robust, adaptive physical systems may be compared to that of similarly robust, adaptive information processing systems, such as the human brain. While potentially damaging, misleading information may gain a hold, abilities to seek out and reference an increasingly integrated (cooperative) knowledge base and intelligently process incongruous (competitive) information, potentiates humanity's accumulation and ability to access ever greater stores of useful information.

div.head: Phase transitions and punctuated equilibrium: emergent traits and motivations
div.p: Perfectly cooperative stable systems cannot evolve. Evolution requires some disruption: some competition. The evolutionary sequence leading from quantum particles to humanity can be considered in terms of transitions between stable systems in agreement with Novikoff's (1945) integrative levels of organization. In the beginning, competition between quantum particles resolved into the cooperative systems of hydrogen and helium atoms. In the more energetic environments of An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials) supernovae the stability of these systems was disrupted again, sometimes repeatedly, before their components stabilized into a sequence of heavier elements. In turn, these collided, forming stable molecules. These were drawn together by gravitational attraction to form new stars, including our sun, and associated planetary systems. On Earth further transitions brought about the emergence and evolution of meteorological, geological, and geomorphic processes. Through these, a succession of increasingly complex molecular systems evolved, paving the way to life (e.g., Salthe, 2010;Steffen et al. 2020).

While uncertainty remains concerning the precise origins of life, the 'RNA World' theory (Rich, 1965), which has ribonucleic acid as the immediate pre-cursor to the last common ancestor of life on Earth, remains one of the best supported (e.g., Rana & Ankri, 2016). Whatever the first living molecule, many evolutionary stages may have passed before prokaryotic cells established themselves as cooperating systems of previously independent replicators (Queller & Strassmann, 2009). Over approximately 4 billion years organismic evolution brought about the emergence of eukaryotes, archeans, algae, plants, fungi, and countless more, increasingly complex, organisms (Betts et al, 2018;Dawkins, 2005).

The sequential emergence of increasingly complex and energy-efficient systems may be regarded in terms of phase transitions. In these, pre-existing components are reconfigured and recombined into new stable forms that best satisfy the second law of thermodynamics given localised environmental constraints. These emergent entities will most likely have different traits from their constituent parts. So, while, for example, the basic systematic building blocks of neutrons and atoms are neutrally charged, their constituents (respectively: up and down quarks, and protons and electrons) are positively and negatively charged. Consequently, they are motivated to behave differently with respect to electromagnetic fields. Different configurations of these atomic constituents endow the elements of the periodic table with different traits. For example, those of helium render it an inert, colorless gas in the Earth's environment, yet when those of three atoms of helium transition into single atoms of carbon, they manifest themselves as a chemically active, electrically conductive, black solid. The electron structure of helium renders its valence shell complete, and as such provides it with no motivation to react with other chemicals, whereas carbon is 'willing' to bond with itself and other atoms. This adaptability lending it to become an essential component of all organisms: representing 18.5% by mass of the human body (Shah, 2015).
The novel traits of emergent systems are particular to the local environment in which they emerge.

At room temperature, water is an electrically conductive liquid, in contrast to its non-conductive gaseous components of hydrogen and oxygen. Water becomes gaseous at 100 O C and solid as 0 O C, losing much of its conductivity. Even fundamental traits such as the mass of particles are determined by their interactions with the Higgs (1964) Field: an all-pervasive quantum field. As previously discussed, the fitness-enhancing potential of organismic traits are similarly context dependent.

Behavioral traits mediate between the needs of an organism and its environment (e.g., Sih et al., 2003). Genes that promote behaviors best adapted to satisfying an organism's survival and reproductive needs will be preferred by natural selection. As such, they may be considered products of interactions between the systems of organisms and the systems of their environment.
Consequently, in the sweep of millions of years of evolution, they may be considered transitory.

Therefore, if we are seeking fundamental truths about the nature of human psychology, including personality, behavioral traits can only provide indirect clues. They are ultimately products of interactions between fundamental motives (directly related to the second law of thermodynamics) and the environment in which they are expressed.

Previously stable non-living systems may be destabilized by inputs of energy that exceed their ability to maintain cooperative order through absorption and emission. Once this happens displaced components compete to establish new relationships that minimize their TPE in the context of their changed environment (see fig. 3). In chemistry, the energy required to initiate these transitions is known as activation energy. Fig. 3 shows a transition in which the TPE of an evolving local system is lowered. Previously stable systems may be broken into simpler components in certain environments, such as when water molecules are split into atoms of hydrogen and oxygen by electrolysis. However, in accordance with Novikoff's (1945) concept of integrative levels, the evolutionary history of the universe suggests a trend toward greater complexity and integration. The components of pre-existing stable systems with unique properties are recombined into newly emergent stable systems with their own characteristic properties. The distinctive properties of organisms, and in turn of humanity, being no different in this respect (Adami et al, 2000).

div.head: Fig. 3 Phase transition between stable cooperative states
div.p: Unlike atoms, which are mostly unbreakable in the environmental conditions found on Earth, molecules tend to be more easily destabilized. Those of carbon dioxide, for example, are decomposed as part of photosynthesis in plants (Singhal, 1999). The energies required to move more complex arrangements of unbound molecules of gas and sand in CAS of persistent weather and dune systems may be even lower. Consequently, while whole systems of loosely or unbound components may endure for extended periods, localised transitions involving the relocation/recycling of their constituents may be continuous.

div.head: An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials)
div.p: The Briggs-Rauscher (1973) reaction between hydrogen peroxide and an iodate is an example of a chemical system capable of sustaining dynamic patterns of orderly behavior. Cycles of sudden color change between amber and dark blue take place as concentrations of the reactants rise and fall (see kviht, 2012). While the oscillating reactions may persist for many minutes, the reaction gradually comes to an end as the reactants are exhausted.

div.head: Fig. 4 Energy exchanges in far-from-equilibrium systems
div.p: Where previously stable systems undergo single phase transitions, such far-from-equilibrium systems may transition between multiple micro-states with near continuous energy exchanges (see fig.4). In weather and sand dune systems the activating source of energy comes from the external environment, whereas in the Briggs-Rauscher (1973) it appears to come from within. However, from the perspective of each reactant, the other effectively defines its environment. Such dynamic systems may be said to comprise components pursuing competitive strategies, yet they maintain orderly structures. In the case of dunes, most of the sand grains cooperate in maintaining the structure of each dune. The management of change/evolution involves competition between a relatively small proportion of sand grains and the external environment. Functionally, organisms also manage the competitive processes of change while maintaining relatively stable cooperative systems of cellular components (Nowak & Highfield, 2012). Over many generations they evolve through relatively minor changes to their genetic code -consequences of competition between genesdeveloping upon, but largely maintaining, existing genetic building blocks (Holland, 1995;.

In addition to the continuous changes and gradual evolution (gradualism) described above, equivalents of phase transitions are apparent in organismic evolution. Systemic organismenvironment interactions may tend toward equilibrium states that reduce variation and appear to slow the pace of evolution . However, when these larger systems are themselves subjected to disruptive events they too may undergo major evolutionary changes over relatively short periods. For example, the Chicxulub asteroid impact 66 million years ago destroyed three quarters of the planet's plant and animal species (Alvarez, 1983), clearing environmental niches that birds and mammals evolved to fill (Falkowski et al., 2005). Such events provide the equivalent of activation energy and trigger phase transitions in punctuated equilibrium (Eldridge & Gould, 1972) or quantum evolution (Simpson 1944). Even within twenty generations of an organism, environmental changes may give rise to quantum evolutionary leaps (Wineguard et al.

div.head: Universal motives for change
div.p: The foregoing suggests that competition and cooperation are important considerations in evolution.

Rather than proceeding smoothly toward maximum entropy, the universe evolves through localised oscillations between order and disorder: cooperation and competition. The evolution of increasingly complex systems, including organisms, humanity, and psychology, is a consequence of competition between cooperative strategies. The most efficient are those whose cooperative endeavours produce the most work per unit of energy input. These are preferred by natural selection and so become building blocks for greater systems.

div.head: An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials)
div.p: CAS such as organisms, comprising many dynamically stable subsystems, represent multi-layered islands of relatively cooperative stability afloat in a sea of chaotic competition. Collisions between them threaten their stability yet provide opportunities to evolve. describes them as existing near the edge of chaos: between stasis and chaos. Perfect cooperation may be associated with the former and unfettered competition with the latter. However, due to gravitational and electromagnetic attraction, competition tends to be resolved in localised equilibrium or, in the case of CAS, dynamic stability. Accordingly, the universe may be considered a dynamic system in which cooperative and competitive strategies are intimately and inextricably entwined. Considered in this way it is apparent cooperation and competition, and their relationships with change, could be considered components of a universal motivational fractal. system of values system of values is a well-established motivational model that explores the relationships between stability and change, and cooperation and competition. named the poles of its orthogonal axes as conservation and openness to change, and selftranscendence and self-enhancement. Fig. 5 shows this basic structure rendered as a universal motivational map. Justified by functional correspondence (e.g., Aelenei et al., 2020) competition replaces self-enhancement, change replaces openness to change, and cooperation replaces selftranscendence. Replacing anthropocentric terminology with terms applicable to any system makes it easier to bridge perceptual divisions between the motives of humanity, other organisms, and nonliving systems.

Prior to the emergence of organisms, all stable systems conserved energy through the cooperation of their components, and so can be said to have motives belonging to the conservation/cooperation quadrant. They change and evolve because of random collisions with other systems (or fundamental particles) moving chaotically through their shared environment. In this sense, the motivation for change comes from without.

Dynamic systems, such as storms and dunes, seem to have components exhibiting cooperative and competitive strategies. However, the latter are directly induced by involuntary interactions with their environment. Only with the emergence of living systems are motivations for competition and change internalised to facilitate sustainable dynamic stability.

div.head: Motives for competition and change
div.p: For some, the significant divides between humanity and our ape ancestors, between mammals and single celled organisms, and between life and inanimate matter, seem too great to be traversed by gradual evolution through chaotic collisions. However, that is the conclusion scientists are drawn to (e.g., Salthe, 2010;Steffen et al. 2020). Therefore, rather than confine considerations of the evolution of human psychology within the framework of 300,000 years of homo sapiens, we might do well to embrace the more radical framework suggested by Gell-Mann (1994), Holland (1995), , and others. Until the emergence of life, it seems no sustainable local system could harness motivations to initiate competition, change, and innovate. Yet, as history attests, the universal system did. It would be consistent with the observations and models of those studying CAS (e.g., Gell-Mann, Holland, Kauffman, Simon, etc.) that smaller CAS should evolve within the greater CAS of which they are part An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials) and replicate aspects of their structure. In so doing they betray something of the shared 'algorithm' that generated them by illuminating something of the relationship between traits and underlying motivations. Newly emergent systems may have novel traits, but these are derived from those of their constituents, which are in turn derived from the universal laws of physics as they play out in systemic interactions. So, while the neutral charge of the first hydrogen atoms was a novel trait that distinguished them from their proton and electron constituents, it derived from the sum of the positive and negative charges of their components, which were retained. The much later emergence of such novel traits as flight and consciousness in the complex systems of organisms can also be derived from pre-existing traits of pre-existing component systems.

Organisms first took flight approximately 400 million years ago (Dunning, 2014). Prior to this, as now, leaves, seeds, and inorganic matter would have been transported above the Earth's surface by air currents. The aerodynamic traits that facilitate flight were already in place. Evolution simply facilitated the emergence of mechanisms for flight from pre-existing interactions between systems.

It did so via many phase transitions, likely including mechanisms that assist gliding in modern species (e.g., Siddall et al., 2020). Flight appears to have evolved four times independently in insects, birds, bats, and pterosaurs (Dawkins, 2005;Hunter, 2007). This suggests the building blocks of the mechanisms of flight were/are widely available.

Consciousness is difficult to define (Tononi & Koch, 2015), let alone date its emergence. Cabanac et al. (2009) contemplate evidence from neural correlates to suggest emergence in amniota (animals that produce embryos in amniotic sacks) about 340 million years ago (Benton & Donoghue, 2007).

However, Tononi's (2004) integrated information theory suggests it needn't be exclusively associated with organisms (Tononi & Koch, 2015). Consciousness involves modeling the internal and external environment to aid goal-directed activity (e.g., Pennartz et al., 2019). As such, it demands, at the very least, abilities to gather, process, store, and relay information. The simplest atomic systems can do this by absorbing and emitting streams of information in the form of photons and processing them by 'deciding' the energy levels and directions of each emission. It also demands abilities to register and respond to this information in ways that facilitate awareness of a discrete host system (a 'self') in relation to its environment. When considered in relation to the closed loops within the brain-body system described by Kotchoubey (2018) and the feedback loops of CAS, this suggests consciousness requires no more than complex rearrangements of pre-existing capabilities.

If so, the evolution of the full gamut of human psychology, including the traits associated with motives in the other three quadrants of our universal motivational map, and, by association, the values of model, can be traced back to before the emergence of organisms.

Organisms are CAS (e.g., Adami et al., 2002;Brown, 1995) comprising many chemical components with low activation energies, that maintain near equilibrium states that are highly responsive to environmental changes (Ross & Berry, 2008). As such, each component may be compared to a strategically placed grain of sand in a system of dunes, ready to fall into a location most advantageous to the system's orderly progression.

The first organism (like all subsequent lifeforms) would have been a molecular system that maintained a far-from-equilibirum state by absorbing and dissipating energy from and to its environment. Unlike inanimate systems, it had acquired the capacity to sustainably procure and process this energy (e.g., Mossel & Steel, 2005). Since the detail of how life emerged from non-life remains moot (e.g., Sousa et al., 2013), for the purposes of this discussion all that needs to be acknowledged is that the first organisms evolved almost 4 billion years ago (Betts et al, 2018). From then on, in accordance with the second law, natural selection preferred those able to process the greatest amount of energy most efficiently toward their own survival and reproduction (England, 2015). This effectively gave rise to an arms race in the battle for access to resources: initially sources of food/energy and then, two million years later, to sexual partners (Zimmer, 2009). The first organisms may have been relatively passive components in the game of life: more like hands of cards in poker than players. Over time, natural selection imbued organisms with increasingly complex mechanisms, enabling even bacteria and plants to initiate competitive behavior (Hibbing et comparing these with previously stored information (memory) (Bezdek, 1992). Even bacteriaamong the earliest evolved organisms -appear to have these capabilities (Jacob et al., 2004;Stock & Zhang, 2013).

As stated previously, evolution through natural selection involves carrying forward and building upon high-fitness building blocks. Stable, cooperative atomic and molecular systems represent the most basic of these. Organisms, like all other stable systems, require cooperating components: organelles, cells, organs, and integrating systems that work together to sustain and reproduce their host. Yet, the dynamism of each relies on highly constrained, subordinated competition. An important example being the electrochemical disequilibrium responsible for adenosine triphosphate (ATP) synthesis, which performs key functions in all cellular activity (Pfeiffer et al., 2001).
Cooperation may be manifested externally between and with sexual partners, offspring, group/colony members, and even unrelated species in symbiotic relationships .

However, organismic interactions with the environment tend to be competitive: mechanisms that strip energy from other systems, including other organisms (e.g., digestion and metabolism), predatorial and defence mechanisms, and sexual reproductive strategies that seek to attract mates in competition with others. Such competitive strategies are outward facing and subordinated to serve the cooperative interests of the local systems of organisms. As such, they evolved to include An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials) capacities for aggression, deception, and dishonesty (e.g., Bond & Robinson, 1988;Hauser, 1992;Proctor, 1991), and for being unforgiving and unhelpful (see , Hibbing et al., 2010.

When unmoderated competitive strategies evolve within a local system, as happens when mutations cause cells to become cancerous, dynamic stability may be undermined by the unsustainable demands they impose (Nowak and Highfield, 2012). As in the Prisoners Dilemma, in the short-term, the competitive strategy of cancerous cells pays off, inflicting many rounds of 'sucker's pay-offs' on the greater system of the organism, but it ultimately accelerates their mutual demise.

div.head: Motivations for creativity and innovation
div.p: While natural selection facilitated organisms gaining traits better adapted to increasingly competitive environments, the primary motivation for change remained external in the earliest phases of their evolution. The genetic mutations responsible arose from random collisions between high energy particles and the DNA (or RNA) of organisms, or random copying errors (Pray, 2008)possibly arising from random sub-atomic quantum fluctuations (Slocombe et al., 2022). Traits over which an organism has no executive control, such as those relating to basic physiology, are those most easily recognised as being directly programmed by genes. However, since all organisms are dynamic CAS that exist within dynamic and often unpredictable environmental CAS, some programmed allowance for localised executive control is also to be expected.

Phenotypic plasticity is the ability of a fixed genotype to produce many phenotypes (Pigliucci et al., 2006). It arises from the equivalent of Holland's (1995) 'if-then' genetic programming. It enables organisms to respond differently to different environmental stimuli. Accordingly, while some ability to instigate change is universal in organisms, this may amount to no more than automated selection from a relatively small, genetically determined menu in accordance with prescriptive criteria. Just as identical DNA in the nuclei of somatic cells facilitates their developing specialised forms and functions dependent on their relative locations (e.g., Holland, 1995), this does not require an internalized pro-change, creative, or innovative motivation.

div.head: An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials)
div.p: To instigate change in ways that suggest a pro-change, competitive motivation associated with the competition/change quadrant of the motivational map requires an ability to deviate from a genetically determined menu. As the competitive traits of organisms evolved to become more sophisticated, they would have demanded more powerful and flexible mechanisms for gathering, processing, recording, and recalling information to inform decision-making.

Given that it can be argued freewill is an illusion (e.g., Dennett, 2015), the emergence of more sophisticated, flexible, and apparently self-directed decision-making mechanisms may be regarded simply a result of more layers of finely-tuned 'if-then' programming over which an organism has no effective control. An alternative perspective is that evolution equipped increasingly complex and individualized organisms with increasingly complex decision-making mechanisms able to adapt to the unpredictable, non-linear behavior of environmental CAS (e.g., Franch-Gras et al., 2017;Heisenberg, 2009;Wingfield, 2013) in ways that imparted some level of independent executive control. The conscious entity (the 'self') that makes such decisions is an emergent phenomena borne of complex interactions in the CAS of brain and body (Thompson & Varela, 2001). As with all other emergent phenomena, this evolved through many phase transitions.
All organisms must be able to tolerate at least short periods of unproductive activity (Grime, 1977).

The greater the resources available to them, the greater this tolerance is likely to be. However, because no activity is cost free, an organism's return on energy invested in 'unproductive' activity will inform judgement by natural selection. Accordingly, it may effectively be considered an organism's research and development budget. Apparently random search patterns such as 'Levy Flights' (Mandelbrot, 1982) that insects, birds, sharks, and turtles use to satisfy a goal have been genetically programmed to optimise the chances of doing so in uncertain environments (Guinard & Korman, 2021;Humphries at al., 2012). Comparable exploratory behavior is witnessed in cells in the erection of microtubules in the construction of cytoskeletons (Kirschner & Mitchison, 1986). Natural selection has seemingly honed these behaviors to minimize risk in unavoidably risky situations. The greater the eventual return from any related discoveries and innovations, the greater the An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials) competitive advantage bestowed, and the greater the selection pressure that can be expected to come to bear on facilitating genes.

div.head: Viewed within narrow temporal and spatial parameters, components of behaviors such as Levy
div.p: Flights may seem devoid of purpose due to the incomplete picture of the environment afforded. The same could be said for playful behavior. This may be described as not fully functional (Burghardt, 2005) because it seems to offer no immediate survival or reproductive benefit. Given natural selection tends to eliminate comparatively inefficient mechanisms and behaviors, an inherent motivation for such behavior could only evolve in organisms able to maintain sufficient energy reserves over periods long enough for delayed benefits to be revealed. While individuals in dominant species seem best placed to develop such reserves, dominance promotes population growth, and so increased competition between individuals, which will tend to erode surplus.

In complex ecosystems, it may be that certain factors limit population growth of a species while others preserve a surplus of resources on which they depend in environmental niches. Also, if organisms are sufficiently adaptive that their population may disperse to other environments, intraspecies competition may be diluted. Whatever the means, genes for increasingly playful and adventurous behavior are only likely to have evolved if the returns on related 'research and development' exceeded the opportunity costs of not investing in more direct need-satisfying activities.

That such behavior tends only to be exhibited by animals in the absence of threats to fitness (e.g., Burghardt, 2005;Dawkins, 2006) seems to confirm its fitness-enhancing potential is served by motivations relating to less urgent needs: e.g., better preparing animals for future threats and opportunities (Held & Spinka, 2011). That such activity is not usually associated with organisms lacking intelligence, and seemingly becomes more frequent and pronounced with higher intelligence, suggests its fitness-enhancing potential is a function of intelligence. This fits with the case made for a link between playfulness and creativity, and between propensities for these and fitness (Bateson, 2014).

We humans are not alone in our capacity for playful and adventurous activity. Other apes (Pellegrini et al., 2007), dolphins (Kuczaj & Eskelinen, 2014), dogs (Bekoff, 2015), and octopi (Zylinski, 2015) exhibit similar behaviors. Most usually these are associated with vertebrates with brains large enough to support complex cognitive abilities (Graham & Burghardt, 2010;Zylinski, 2015). For individual organisms, experimentation through playful and adventurous activity replicates the research and development function that mutation and natural selection performs for genomes, but within a single generation. If its purpose is to guide future action with reference to an internal reference model of an organism's environment, as with consciousness (Kotchoubey, 2018), it must be supported by memory and intelligence. Because, playful activity leaves no trace in the fossil record, and even simple organisms can build and update an internal model of their environment to aid decision-making (e.g., Wright, et al., 2023), it is difficult to determine exactly when internalised motivations for playfulness, adventurousness, and creativity emerged.
For the learnings of playful or adventurous experimentation to survive the death of the experimenting organism, they must be communicated to others and stored for onward transmission.

At what stage of evolution this became possible is also difficult to ascertain. Evidence suggests intelligent organisms such as dolphins learn to use tools (Krutzen et al., 2005), whales adapt their calls (Zandberg et al., 2021), rats adopt new feeding behaviors (Heyes & Galef, 1996), and blue tits learn new foraging techniques, such as pecking through foil milk bottle tops (Hinde & Fisher, 1951) by cultural transmission. The creativity that spawns such behavior relates to innovative problem solving, which is thought to be an evolved adaptation to deal with environmental variation (Griffin, 2016). Lefebvre (2013) reports that a domain general intelligence appears to promote innovativeness across species, and suggests that, while many factors including brain size relative to body size and the size of certain areas of the brain correlate positively with innovativeness and tool use, there are many other unidentified factors at work. However, if the creative intelligence of birds and mammals emerged in a shared ancestor, it would suggest a motivation for change within organisms began sometime after 120 million years ago (e.g., Dawkins, 2005;Brusatte et al., 2015).

div.head: Motivations for progressive cooperation
div.p: Other animals' capabilities to explore, discover, and instigate change pale against those of humanity.
Equipped with brains capable of more sophisticated information storage (memory), processing (intelligence), and communication (language), humanity has a unique capacity to instigate change.

The human brain is a CAS that has evolved to become capable of modelling, and feeding back to affect, not only the somatic system of which it is part and its immediate environment, but, increasingly, the universal system beyond (Simon, 1995). No other organism has exhibited comparable capacities for innovation and technological advancement or knowledge of the universe.

Deutsche (2011, p.59) describes humans as universal constructors: "factories for transforming anything into anything". In creating a virtual representation of the sometimes-chaotic behavior of its environment, rather than evolving only in response to involuntary physical interactions, human consciousness has enabled us to initiate reliable virtual interactions in our heads. Abilities to visualise and distinguish between the characteristics of things, and base physical experiments on thought experiments, enable us to solve problems and innovate more efficiently. So efficiently, humanity effectively self-directs its own evolution in relation to an increasingly accurate internal model of the universal system of which it is part.

A key factor in humanity's comparatively rapid evolution from the emergence of homo sapiens a few hundred thousands of years ago appears to be our ability to cooperate (Fuentes, 2004). While cooperation is common in the animal kingdom, our capacity for it is unique (Melis & Semmann, 2010). Through international trade, the sharing of scientific knowledge, and multinational cultural and sporting organizations, we cooperate with peoples with whom we share no intimate connection, and devote time and money to those we perceive to be in situations less fortunate than ourselves.

An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials) Symbiotic cooperative relations are common in nature, but these are explicable in terms of genetic co-evolution in exactly the same way as parasitically competitive relationships are .

The genes of ants and aphids have evolved in harmony with each other because of the benefits of inter-species cooperation . By contrast, the genes of British cuckoos and the parasitic fungus ophiocordyceps unilateralis have evolved to exploit the resources of the external systems of other birds (Glue & Morgan, 1972) and ants (Lu, 2019) respectively. Such competitive strategies are only sustainable when co-evolution constrains exploitation to avoid resource depletion (Papkou et al., 2016). The preparedness of humans to help other species is not confined to those we wish to raise for food or clothing. We gain pleasure and satisfaction from tending to all manner of plants and animals, even those with the potential to harm us. Our willingness to cooperate is driven by motivations that range from the personal gratification gained from keeping a pet to an awareness that we depend upon an ecosystem shared with eight billion other humans and countless other As humanity evolved greater experimental capabilities and developed more reliable and widely framed models of its environment, it would have been better able to innovate and better target its growing research and development budget. The feedback loop involved would have potentiated the type of exponential growth describes in his law of accelerating returns. The demands and benefits accruing may have brought selection pressure to bear on genes for higher intelligence. Maybe this is reflected in the increases in intelligence reported as the Flynn (1987) effect. defines values as beliefs linked inextricably to affect that refer to desirable goals. They serve as standards or criteria that transcend specific actions and situations, ordered by importance to motivate action. They are abstract concepts, not physical things, emotions, or actions.

div.head: Evolutionary equivalents of human values
div.p: We evaluate the worth of physical things with our values; emotions are aroused by environmental interactions with values, and, broadly speaking, we experience positive emotions when we live in accordance with our values, and negative emotions when they are frustrated . As such they appear to operate according to Holland's (1995) 'if-then' programming: if positive emotions are aroused, approach; if negative emotions are aroused, avoid. This represents a complex aggregation of the binary 'perceptions' and actions of individual electrons described earlier 3 .

While other values models exist, the system is the most widely adopted in psychological research. Its structure and values appear near universal and largely stable Sagiv & Schwartz, 2022). It has been used to reveal, for example, systematic influences on consumer behavior (Shaw et al., 2005), political choices (Caprara et al., 2006), and leadership style (Copeland, 2014), and systematic effects of upbringing (Griffiths et al., 2021), peer relations (Benish-Weisman et al., 2022), and migration (Lonngvist et al., 2011). It has also been found to be the best predictor of prosocial behavior, mental health, and pro-environmental behavior (Hanel et al., 2018).

However, as with any construct explored by self-reports, the detail capable of being revealed is subject to many human limitations (e.g., Garcia & Gustavson, 1997;McDonald, 2008): not least of which is matching words and interpretations thereof to consciously inaccessible neurological mechanisms. Therefore, while the evidence suggests the system of values broadly represents the human motivational system, it may be a low-resolution representation: more reliable in revealing its general structure than the detailed relationships between highly localised elements.
Accordingly, it is in this light that the broad correspondence we suggest between evolutionary expectations relating to the UMM and Schwartz's 10 values should be viewed.

The Schwartz model includes 56 to 58 universally accepted values, such as honesty, curiosity, and ambition, grouped under the 10 value headings shown in figs. 1 and 5. Correlations between the ranked importance and influences exerted by these values allows them to be mapped with respect to each other and two orthogonal axes representing their affinities with change: conservation to openness to change, and strategic purpose of change: self-enhancement to self-transcendence .

Values adjacent to each other tend to serve similar needs and promote similar behaviors, whereas opposing values tend to correlate negatively, both in the behaviors they promote and how they are prioritized by individuals (Bardi & Schwartz, 2003;. Differences in the prioritization and relative importance individuals attach to values characterise them as individuals: influencing beliefs, attitudes, and behaviors, and shaping personalities (e.g., Bardi & Schwartz, 2003;Dobewall et al, 2014;Griffiths et al, 2021). Research Form (Stumpf et al., 1985), concluding the In fig. 5 we allocate values to the four phases of evolution previously described in relation to the quadrants of the UMM shown in fig. 4. Just as the values of the system are arbitrary divisions of a motivational continuum, the phase boundaries are arbitrary divisions of an evolutionary continuum. Of greater importance is the progressive nature of the strategies that may be associated with the hierarchical sequencing of values.

In reading the following it should be borne in mind that, just as evolution proceeds by carrying forward and building upon what went before, the emergence of successive values (or equivalents thereof) should be considered an additive process. Therefore, while opposing values in the circular structure of Schwartz's system may correlate negatively in the behaviors and attitudes they promote, this is because 'higher' values promote alternatives, not necessarily replacements. For example, the desire for and practise of sex in an established relationship may be considered universal 'traditions', but sex outside such is more likely to arise in those with dominant permissive (openness to change) values than those with dominant conservative values (Lawson, 1988).

div.head: An evolutionary hierarchy of human values or their equivalents Phase 1 -Cooperation/Conservation
div.p: The personal value of benevolence facilitates in-group cooperation through, for example, honesty, forgiveness, and helpfulness. The term in-group is used to define the local systems of greatest importance to an individual: their family, friends, or tribe. All stable physical systems, from atoms upwards, are 'honest' in that they have no ability to conditionally manipulate the gravitational and electromagnetic information they broadcast, 'forgiving' in that they respond only to current actions of components, and 'helpful' in that components accommodate each other in maintaining equilibrium. As a facilitator of cooperation, an equivalent of benevolence may be inferred in all stable systems.

The values of tradition and conformity facilitate the replication and continuity of beliefs and behaviors across time (particularly between generations) and space (particularly between individuals An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials) and groups in a single current generation) respectively, so maintaining stability. Stable physical systems such as hydrogen and helium atoms have persisted in the same form for 13.8 billion years, and those in one location are indistinguishable from those in another. The traditions of organisms are primarily carried forward in their genes and passed on through meiosis (the formation of a zygote from gametes). In mitosis and cell division the copying of identical DNA to daughter cells ensures genetic conformity throughout the system of an organism. Reproduction encourages the proliferation of genes that conform to the fittest, most stable specifications in any given environment. Broad conformity of traits is evident among all animals belonging to the same species, and most clearly exemplified by the flocking behavior of bacteria, birds, fish, and wildebeest (Toner et al., 2005).
The value of security includes such components as cleanliness, family security, and national security.

These regulate change in relation to localised boundaries in the interests of safety and stability. The atomic systems of elements regulate the behavior of their components in relation to the prescriptive energy levels and capacities of electron orbitals (Bohr, 1913). Organisms have mechanisms that regulate change internally (e.g., metabolisms and immune systems) in relation to boundaries (e.g., cells and organs), and externally (e.g., nests and protected territories).

div.head: Phase 2 -Conservation/Competition
div.p: The power value relates to desires for status, influence, and control. All things passively exert power through the gravitational or electromagnetic fields surrounding them. However, evolution promotes physical and behavioral characteristics that serve to actively increase or protect the influence and control organisms have over their environment. These might include anything that enables them to evade detection, mislead, escape, overpower, impress, or attract. These attributes are aimed at conserving or improving survival and reproductive opportunities in competitive environments, thereby enhancing an organism's ability to satisfy goals associated with conservative motivations.

div.head: An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials)
div.p: The achievement value relates to the pursuit and advertisement of success in relation to widely accepted standards. For genes and organisms, natural selection effectively sets these standards, favoring: genes that promote success in survival and reproduction; fitness indicators that advertise such capabilities; and capabilities to recognise, distinguish between, and act upon reliable indicators in others. By demonstrating such capabilities, and having them recognised and recorded, organisms may be spared effortful and risky conflict. Zahavi's handicap principle (see Grafen, 1990) explains the evolution of costly displays such as the Peacock's tail in terms of their ability to honestly demonstrate the fitness of their owner, since they are too costly for less fit organisms to bear. To give an equivalent behavioral example, once a male chimpanzee has demonstrated his dominance he may then be spared constant challenges from others (Waal, 1986). However, such mechanisms can be subverted. Organisms may evolve characteristics that falsely advertise qualities they do not possess, whether to deter or attract others (e.g., Bond & Robinson, 1988), so giving rise to an evolutionary arms race between genes for improved detection and discrimination and genes for better deception.

div.head: Phase 3 -Competition/Change
div.p: Hedonism promotes behavior that is fun, playful, and pleasureable in its own right. Behavior not directed at satisfying basic survival or reproductive needs may be less linear and more experimental. Accordingly, it offers greater potential for generating learning opportunities. Stimulation more directly promotes learning through a greater prepareness to take risks in the pursuit of variety and novelty.

Just as mutation and natural selection effectively enable successive generations of organisms to innovate, hedonism and stimulation potentiate this within the lifetime of an organism. Once innovations and learnings can be culturally transmitted to others, the effects may trickle down to better satisfy the goals associated with equivalents of 'lower' values; spreading through a population and down through generations to eventually replace long standing behavioral traditions. In stable An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials) organism-environment systems, selection pressure may come to bear on enabling genes, so updating 'traditional' gene combinations as well as culturally inherited traits.

div.head: Phase 4 -Change/Cooperation
div.p: Self-direction promotes independent thought and action, curiosity and creativity. As such, it facilitates a more targeted approach to experimentation and learning, and the pursuit of discoveries that facilitate more effective courses of action. Universalism promotes a desire for wisdom, developing a greater understanding and affinity with nature, with concerns for the environment, social justice, and equality. Self-direction and universalism feed each other, potentiating greater selfreliance, inner harmony, an appreciation of one's place in the universe, and so an understanding of the virtues of cooperation. A likely consequence of this being a motivation for less constrained forms of benevolence.

In line with the previously described relationship between progressive and cooperative motivation and intelligence and knowledge, these values seem to have the greatest potential to promote better decision-making. The greater efficiency so potentiated should create trickle down benefits for satisfying the goals associated with lower values: more opportunities to learn and have fun, less need to devote energy to proving oneself, or asserting ones influence or control over others, and less need to cling to and protect what one already has.

div.head: Experimental evidence
div.p: Given their role in decision-making and how we suggest they evolved, it seems likely that values exert hierarchical influences to complement the known circular influences, and not just in relation to values laden propositions. To explore this, we tested a large group of individuals with a range of decision-making tasks, including Kahneman and Tversky type propositions intended to explore values-related heuristic biases, Raven's Progressive Matrices (RPM; and a Guilford et al.'s (1978) Alternative Uses Test (GAUT) of creativity. The size of the correlations between the relative importance given to individual values and performance in these tests underplays their influence. Because values operate as components of a system, even small, statistically insignificant differences in single value prioritization can promote large differences in the decision-making of differently motivated people. For example, when 1316 participants were divided into five motivational types 4 , those allocated to a group for whom hedonism and stimulation were the most important values were more than twice as likely to risk a £100 loss for a potential £200 win on the toss of a coin than those belonging to a group for whom the conservation values were the most important (40% compared to 18%), despite no single value accounting for more than 4% of the variance (see fig. SM7). In respect of another challenge, concerning the allocation of healthcare budget, the largest single value/response correlation was responsible for little more than 0.5% of the variation in responses but contributed to a significant 28% difference in the average choices of two motivational types (see fig. SM8).
An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials) Preference for a £25% chance to lose nothing and a 75% of losing £1,000 rather than taking a £750 loss for certain (below) N=1313.

div.head: Other supportive evidence
div.p: If good quality, independent decision-making promotes happiness, as would appear to be the case (Benz & Frey, 2004;Chuang, 2007;Kurtz, 2007), one might anticipate that nations in which the higher values of self-direction, universalism, and benevolence are more important would be among the happiest. Conversely, those in which conservative values are more important should be among the least happy. Comparison of the World Values Survey (WVS, 2023) 5 and the World Happiness Report (WHR, 2021) 6 supports this conjecture. Those nations having the most selfexpressive/secular-rational values -which correspond with self-direction and universalism values -are found to rank amongst the happiest in the WHR: Sweden 7th, Norway 5th, Denmark 2nd, Finland 1st, and the Netherlands 6 th , whereas those with the most survival/traditional values ranked among the least happy: Jordan 119th (of 153), Yemen 146th, Zimbabwe 151st, Morocco 97th, and Ghana 91st. 5 A periodic international survey of the values of representative samples of adults conducted by a global cooperative of social scientists. The 7th wave covers the years 2017-2022 drawing from data collected from over 120,000 individuals in 79 nations. 6 An annual survey of representative samples of 1,000 to 3,000 adults per nation in 153 nations conducted by Gallup and published by the United Nations Sustainable Development Solutions Network. Respondents are asked to rate their current happiness with their lives on a scale of 0 (worst possible life) to 10 (best possible life). Consistent findings also emerge from comparison of values with Hierarchy of Needs, and research carried out in relation to the latter. As shown in the supplementary materials (see fig.SM1 and accompanying review), the values attributed by Research supportive of Maslow's hierarchy (e.g., , when viewed through the lens of Schwartz's values, is perhaps supportive of the evolutionary theory of values advanced here. However, the lack of any widely accepted, valid, and reliable means of measuring Maslow's hierarchy of needs (Lester, 2013) makes it likely that An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials) much of this could be lost in translation. More promising is the support provided by research into the effects of transformational leadership (Bass, 1985). This is a well-established leadership model based on eupsychian management (management according to self-actualizing principles) (Burns, 2004). Transformational leadership has shown to be beneficial in many areas, including: engagement and preparedness to change (Faupel & Süß, 2019), team effectiveness (Özaralli, 2003), individual and team performance and helping behavior (Wang & Howell, 2010), creativity (Shafi et al., 2020), organizational performance, learning, and innovation (Para-González, 2018), improving organizational knowledge and related decision-making , and effective, satisfying, and effort-evoking leadership and parenting (Zacharatos et al., 2000).

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: The coincidence of experimental and other evidence consistent with there being a linear, hierarchical structure to human values that complements the known circular structure lends plausibility to our evolutionary theory of values. That this is predicted by no other theory we are aware of suggests it is worthy of further investigation.

It is suggested that any evolutionary theory should address Tinbergen's (1963) four questions relating to function (why), evolution (how), causation (what), and development (how). The function of values is to guide decision-making toward the satisfaction of needs ). As we have explained, all needs can be derived from the universal need for systems to move toward equilbrium in accordance with the second law of thermodynamics. All decision-making mechanisms can be traced back to the binary 'choices' of atoms of whether to absorb and emit photons or not. The mechanism by which they operate has evolved through layers of increasing complexity such that values-based decisions represent aggregates of countless layers of these binary 'decisions': from those of atomic electrons to those of neurons. Equivalents of values-based decision-making have evolved through countless phase transitions in increasingly complex CAS and their constituents in An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials) terms that can be related to the UMM. The dynamic relationship between cooperation, competition and change captured by the UMM, and reflected in the structure of system, plays out at every emergent level of complexity.

Given the radical nature of this theory and its relevance to the evolution of all systems, its implications and applications are too numerous to discuss here. Other than those related to psychology, and through psychology to all human systems, it offers an opportunity to consider the evolution of other systems in relateable human terms. A summary of suggested areas of interest is provided in the supplementrary materials, along with the perspective it offers on established psychological theory, including personality theories other than the Big Five. Here we will confine ourselves to addressing the aspirations and concerns of Block (2010) mentioned at the beginning of this paper: those relating to the five factor model and the state of personality science.

We have argued that the structure of a UMM equivalent to that of Schwartz's system is comprehensive, universal, and inescapable, in that all systemic interactions cannot escape being considered in terms of their propensity to change, and the degrees of cooperation and competition between their components. It therefore fulfils the requirement of an adaptive paradigm capable of generating sufficient surface complexity from great simplicity.

Our research into the effects of upbringing on the personalities of only-children when compared to those on siblings (Griffiths et al., 2021) found significant effects on power and benevolence values consistent with the popular stereotype that has only-children as being more selfish. Previous research based on traits had concluded that either there was no such effect (Polit and Falbo, 1987), or any effect was too small to be noticeable (Stronge, et al., 2019). An explanation for this, which may relate to many aspects of personality, is that the same value priorities may find expression in different behavioral traits in different environments. For example, an individual motivated most by power may be motivated to behave in any way they consider likely to maintain or increase their influence in the environment in which they find themselves. If this involves influencing perceived An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials) superiors and others whose goodwill they wish to exploit, this may involve ingratiating, agreeable behavior. In other environments, involving others whose goodwill is considered unimportant, they may prefer dismissive, bullying, or other disagreeable behavior. Given that people who know each other well can read the values of others reliably (Dobewall et al.,, 2014), an individual showing such context dependent duality of personality is likely to be identifiable as being relatively strong on power motivation and relatively low on benevolence. Conversely, given value priorities are considered trans-situationally stable , an individual considered broadly agreeable or disagreeable seems less likely to become fundamentally more or less motivated by self-enhancing or self-transcending values in different environments.

The relationship between values and traits is complex, because both are rooted in genes (Schermer, et al., 2011) and are similarly stable, and subject to environmental change (see review in . Also, while values motivate action (and therefore behavioral traits), consequent behavior changes the environment to which values must adapt. So while they may influence each other 2019), the basic principles of physics tell us that motivation precedes action, with the former arising from, and the latter proceeding in accordance with, the second law of thermodynamics. The behavioral traits of physical systems are particular to circumstantial interactions between proximate systems. They include radioactive emission, bursting into flame, and flight: none of which are easily reconciled with the personalty traits of humans. Yet all arise from competition between systems arising from energetic disequilbrium. Accordingly, at the very least, it seems rational to reconsider the relative roles of values (and their UMM equivalents and precursors) and traits in shaping personality.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The following information provides further background and expands upon the information provided in the main paper: An Evolutionary Theory of Values (EToV). In reading the following it should be borne in mind we are not suggesting perfect congruence between the UMM and Schwartz's model.

The structure of the UMM is theoretically ideal. That its orthogonal axes correspond with those of the Schwartz system justifies our comparison of the two. However, the Schwartz system, particularly its detailed structure, is not theoretically ideal because it is derived from self-reports (e.g., Baumeister et al., 2007;Garcia & Gustavson, 1997).

Apart from issues regarding the construction of self-report questionnaires, the reliability of individual responses and interpretations thereof are subject to human error. In the following we will An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials) identify potential issues relating to the measurement of self-direction and universalism, and the lack of allowance for systematic interactions between values in correlation studies. This is not to suggest we believe the Schwartz model is not fit for purpose. The number and quality of studies confirming its validity (see Schwartz, 2012) suggest it is 'good enough' for the purposes of exploring broad structural correspondence with the UMM, and broad sequential relationships between the emergence of evolutionary strategies and values. Accordingly, in these supplementary materials we have been sparing in our use of citations concerning correspondence between Schwartz's values and other models. We have used them illustratively, rather than relying on them, because the proposed structure of the UMM is independently justifiable.

Also, our research to date does not allow us to separate the influence of values from their UMM equivalents. If values operate consciously, pre-consciously, and unconsciously, it is likely the underlying neurological mechanisms are shared with deeper motivations related to the UMM.

Therefore, when we discuss the influence of values on mental health in SM4, it should be borne in mind that when considering yet to be explored relationships it would be better to infer no clear distinctions between values and unconscious UMM equivalents.

div.head: SM1 Selected core principles relevant to the evolution of the universe
div.p: (1) Quantum uncertainty.
