The fundamental constituents of all energy, and therefore of all matter and organisms, can be considered in terms of quantum particles (for overview see Peskin & Schroeder, 1995) that observe prescriptive energy levels particular to each element, the configuration of which determines the chemical characteristics of each element: i.e., how they relate to and interact with one another (for summary see Bertsch et al., 2023).

(3) Gravitational and electromagnetic fields 7 effectively connect all sub-systems of the universe. They imbue them with potential energy: i.e., a motive for change. Gravitation exerts a relatively weak attractive force between massive objects. Electromagnetic attraction (between oppositely charged particles) and repulsion (between like charged particles) exerts a vastly greater force. However, repulsive and attractive forces tend to cancel each other out over large distances due to the likely proximity of differently charged particles. Hence electromagnetism tends to exert the greatest influence over proximate systems such as the nervous systems of organisms, whereas gravity is the dominant influence shaping the greater physical environments organisms inhabit. The influence of both declines in proportion to the square of the distance from their source. Nevertheless, due to the infinite reach of these fields, all things contribute to the environment of all other things, and therefore sub-systems evolve with respect to each other and the larger systems of which they are part (see Gupta, 1954).

(4) The first law of thermodynamics states that energy can neither be destroyed nor gained in a closed system, i.e., one isolated from all others such that no energy may flow in or out. The universe is a closed system. Therefore, any energy lost from or gained by its local subsystems (such as atoms, molecules, genes, organisms, and ecosystems) must be compensated by gains to or losses from their environment (i.e., the other sub-systems of the universe). The relevance of this to the evolution of systems, and therefore to natural selection, is that all costs and benefits experienced by or attributed to a local system are balanced out across the universal system. More colloquially, 'there's no such thing as a free lunch' (see Iwase, 2014). 5The second law of thermodynamics states that in a closed system 8 entropy (disorder) tends to increase. Energy flows from hot to cold, high concentrations to low, until equilibrium is reached. This is related to the minimum total potential energy principle, which states that local systems tend to deform until the potential energy of their components has been minimized. During the process of deformation (or reconfiguration) excess energy is lost from the system in the form of heat. Chemicals reactions are only potentiated when they lead to an increase in entropy. Mostly this arises when combinations of atoms and molecules deform into more energy-efficient configurations, giving off heat in the process (exothermic reactions). However, some reactions may be initiated by heating, such that highly localised, less energy-efficient configurations can be sustained by the absorption of energy (endothermic reactions). In such reactions, increases in the entropy of the external systems providing the heat exceed the decrease in the entropy of the local system of reactants. The second law also finds equivalence in the principle of least action, which dictates that particles and systems minimize their total potential energy by following the most energyefficient paths. This explains why objects are drawn directly down toward the earth's centre of gravity, light is deflected (refracted) when passing between media with different densities (e.g., water and air), and projectiles follow a parabolic path determined by balancing the downward force of gravity and their horizontal momentum. The second law is the principal motivation for change in any system (see Iwase, 2014). (6) Energy transfer between systems is facilitated by photons. Photons are indivisible quanta of energy, each with a specific energy level. As systems deform to minimise their total potential energy, photons are emitted as electrons move to more energy-efficient configurations. As electrons may only occupy atomic orbitals with prescriptive energy levels characteristic of each element, emitted photons have energy levels equal to the energy gaps between orbitals. The wavelengths of the lines in the emission spectra of elements correspond to the gaps between these orbitals. Correspondingly, electrons may only absorb photons if their energy levels match gaps between permitted orbitals. This gives rise to the reciprocal pattern of dark lines in the absorption spectra of elements. Photons with energies that fail to correspond with orbital energy gaps are not absorbed (see Podgoršak, 2014). This effectively means they are not 'perceived'. This is not only analogous to the ways in which humans and other organisms perceive visual information but is a fundamental component of the enabling mechanism: one that facilitates and governs communication between systems. The human eye perceives color across the 400 to 700 nm wavelength range of the electromagnetic spectrum by means of 6-7 million cone cells, each perhaps comprising c.100 trillion atoms (see Mustafi at al., 2009;Spring et al. 2023). These cones are just one part of the complex system that processes visual information. The exchanges of photons convey information between atoms. They do so obeying probabilistic quantum mechanical rules related to the uncertainty principle that prohibit knowing the exact direction and locations they will be emitted and absorbed. This and the incalculable number of atoms involved are important factors contributing to the intractable complexity of the interactions that underpin both how humans process information and, more generally, how evolution proceeds.

An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials) (7) Evolution by natural selection proceeds in accordance with the second law of thermodynamics (Sabater, 2006). Organisms best adapted to their environment -i.e., those with characteristics most advantageous to survival and reproduction -i.e., those able to absorb, process, and invest energy most efficiently toward the satisfaction of their needswill tend to outcompete other organisms seeking to exploit the same resources. The most successful organisms will tend to pass more copies of their genes onto successive generations than others . The fitness of organisms is a function of both genes and environment. The fitness of genetically identical organisms depends on how well adapted to their respective environments they are. No two particles, atoms, or molecules, let alone organisms, may share the same space at the same time, even in otherwise 'shared'
environments. This alone ensures some variation upon which natural selection may act.

Directly imposed genetic variation comes from the mutation of genes. Whether by routine copying errors in DNA replication, or as a consequence of bombardment from high energy photons in their environment, the molecular structure of an organism's DNA is changed such that different chemical instructions are issued and acted upon. These may cause genes to become more or less well adapted to the environments of their genomes, and host organisms to become more or less well adapted to the environmental systems of which they are part ). Wininger & Norman, 2007). In common with all organisms, failure to satisfy physiological needs brings death. A failure to satisfy needs for safety and belonging brings greater risk of harm or death (Olcoń et al., 2017;Van Orden et al., 2010), with attendant adverse effects on physiological and psychological well-being (Cacioppo et al., 2015;Loades, et al., 2020;Rohde et al. 2016), including self-esteem (Hall-Lande et al., 2007). Logically, given fixed resources of time and energy, the more a person invests in gaining the esteem of others, the less will be available for self-actualization. This fits with findings that children with unstable self-esteem exhibit less curiosity and preference for challenge (Waschull & Kernis, 1996).

Despite its popularity, the hierarchy has attracted criticism regarding: the generality of its categories and concepts, and associated difficulties of empirically testing its structural relationships (Schiffman & Kanuk 1997); levels of need appearing to operate independently from others (Wahba & Bridwell, 1976); and its lack of provision for heroic, altruistic, dominant, abasing, playful, and aggressive behavior (Schiffman & Kanuk 1997;Witt & Wright 1992). As others (e.g., O'Connor & Yballe, 2007;Wininger & Norman, 2007) have pointed out, some of this criticism has been misplaced. Maslow An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials) (1943) explicitly stated that multiple levels of need could be active at any one time. As for its alleged omissions, listed status and dominance (which would seem to allow for abasement and aggression) as esteem-need-related values, and playfulness and goodness as self-actualizing values. Self-transcendence is a broad term that would seem to cover heroism and altruism.

Desmet and Fokkinga (2020) believe subsequent research has shown Maslow's theory to have been correct insofar as: human needs are inborn and universal; a broad set of behaviors can be explained by relatively few needs; needs are responsible for motivating behavior; and their satisfaction contributes to well-being Ryff & Keyes, 2000;Tay & Diener, 2011). Taormina and Gao 2013

div.head: Linking Maslow's needs to Schwartz's values
div.p: The terms needs and values were used interchangeably by Maslow (e.g., 1968, p. 153), and taken to mean goals people strive to achieve, which, if frustrated, diminish well-being. While he considered values a term so broad that, without tighter definition, it would likely become obsolete, he expressed the belief that values were an intrinsic, structural component of human nature that were genetically as well as culturally derived (Maslow, 1968, p. 167). Rokeach (1973) and went on to provide the required definition and, using the latter's system, values have since been shown to be heritable (Twito & Knafo-Noam, 2020;Zacharopoulos et al., 2016).

Associations between Schwartz's values and Maslow's needs have previously been made (e.g., Bilsky & Schwartz, 1994;Gau & James, 2003;Kluger et al. 2004). Schwartz (2012) categorises achievement, An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials) power, security, conformity, and tradition values as being prevention of loss (deficiency) orientated (i.e., associated with needs below self-actualization), and benevolence, universalism, self-direction, stimulation, and hedonism as growth values (i.e., associated with self-actualizing needs). However, comparisons tend to fall short of claiming a comprehensive overlap, perhaps because of difficulties in reconciling the circularity of the Schwartz system and the linearity of Maslow's hierarchy.

Nevertheless, when the terminology used in each is compared, (see fig. SM2) sequential correspondence is readily apparent. Maslow links mastery to achievement and esteem related needs. While Schwartz (2012) associates mastery with self-direction, there is no explicit mention of mastery in the PVQ-40 (Schwartz et al., 2001) we used in our research. Perhaps the two descriptions used to assess the importance of selfdirection that most closely relate to it are: 'they like to be curious and to try to understand all sorts of things' and 'they like to rely on themselves'. A desire to become self-reliant and understand many things may be sympathetic to gaining some level of mastery, however, the concepts are not inextricably linked. A similar case could be made for linking the descriptions used to evaluate the importance of achievement, i.e.: 'they want to show how capable they are'; 'they strive to do better than others'; 'being very successful is important to them'; 'they like to impress other people'; 'it is very important to them to show their abilities' and 'they want people to admire what they do'. If the purpose of mastery is to please oneself without reference to others or external benchmarks, or to enable one to complete a task for the same reason, then it relates more to self-direction than achievement. However, if the gratification comes from demonstrating one's capabilities such that others may be impressed, then it better relates to achievement. A third interpretation of mastery is 'control or superiority over someone or something' (Oxford Dictionaries, 2023), which directly relates to power values.

Aside from such quibbles, broad alignment between the two models is apparent. Considering this in the context of the argument presented in the main paper, we are drawn to believe Maslow was prescient in devising his hierarchy. Despite a lack of clarity concerning the precise nature of its operation and how its needs could be assessed, its correspondence with the Schwartz system, especially our hierarchical interpretation of it, suggests it provides a useful description of the human motivational system. By using well established methodology relating to the measurement of Schwartz's values and interpreting findings in accordance with the methodology described in Self-actualization was removed from atop of the pyramid because they considered that "although self-actualization may be of considerable psychological importance, it is unlikely to be a functionally distinct human need" (Kenrick et al., 2010, p. 293). If they are correct in believing Maslow justified the placement of self-actualization on the grounds that it was a functionally distinct human need detached from biological needs, we can agree he was wrong to do so. It is a truism to say no genetic disposition can be separated from its biological root. Also, based on the alignment between Schwartz's self-direction values and Maslow's self-actualization needs, it is apparent that dolphins and chimpanzees are among the intelligent organisms capable of exhibiting self-directing aspects of self-actualization (Morrison & Reiss, 2018). However, neither of these reasons justifies its removal.

While all organisms have some capacity for autonomous action -i.e., their dynamism is not simply reliant on linear reactions to external motivating forces -it is apparent a capacity for self-direction (as well as for generating and referencing reliable models of their environment) increases with intelligence (e.g., McFarland et al., 1993) and is uniquely expressed in humans.

Their suggestion that self-actualization is subsumed within status/esteem related needs appears to arise from a conflagration of distinct aspects of mastery and learning. As they point out, high status is useful because "it is much more efficient to learn by modeling the behaviors of successful others than by using trial and error (Boyd & Richerson, 1985;Henrich & Boyd, 1998), so people are willing to defer to, and perform favors for, others who have acquired skills" (Kenrick et al., 2010, p. 297).

Indeed, the motivation for replicating successful strategies and behaviors replicates the function of natural selection, which we consider to be functionally equivalent to the motivation provided by the value of achievement. However, this form of mastery is limited to replicating what already exists. Therefore, while it may serve a progressive function in raising the average performance/fitness of a population, it does little to drive progress by innovation. Without the introduction of novel components and combinations thereof systems tend to evolve toward equilibrium and stasis .

The type of mastery they describe as being non-specific to status or esteem is that related to curiosity and play. They refer to Deci and Ryan's (2000, p. 252) linkage of these to a domain-general need ''to engage optimal challenges and experience mastery or effectance in the physical and social worlds'' as a problem-solving mechanism. We agree that curiosity and play, motivated by the values of hedonism, stimulation, and self-direction, serve problem-solving functions. However, unlike mastering an already established practise, play and curiosity are more concerned with selfexpression and self-directed discovery. They may lead to the discovery of behaviors and knowledge that one goes on to master, which may then serve as markers of achievement and status, but the initial motivation cannot be for mastery: mastery of something unknown? Self-direction and universalism in their promotion of curiosity, independent thought and action, and a desire to understand a broad range of things encourage mastery in a more general sense. By encouraging innovative thinking, they may push individuals into levels of understanding that make them more capable than those driven to achieve on more constrained terms. If so, they will have achieved higher levels of mastery, albeit they are more likely to realize that complete mastery is an unrealizable goal, in that their state of knowledge can always be improved upon. In common with all motivations, the ultimate 'problem' to be 'solved' is how to best satisfy the second law of thermodynamics. The hierarchical structure of evolving values we present simply represents an increasingly efficient suite of strategies for doing so.

div.head: An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials)
div.p: They suggest that self-actualization, like complex psychological phenomena such as religion and morality, may not serve specific fitness-relevant functions, and may be by-products or nonadaptive effects of other psychological mechanisms. We describe in the main paper the fitness-relevant function of self-actualization through the values of self-direction and universalism, however, it is perhaps worth addressing their treatment of religion and morality, since these would appear similarly rooted in values-based motivation.

Religion provides explanations for why things are as they are. For example: "In the beginning God created the heavens and the earth. Now the earth was formless and empty, darkness was over the surface of the deep, and the Spirit of God was hovering over the waters. And God said, 'Let there be light' and there was light." (Genesis 1:1-3). It also offers related guidance as to how one should go about one's life. The ten commandments of the Christian Bible being an example. In this respect it is little different to science. For religious believers and scientists alike, religion and science offer the most appealing explanations for why things are as they are and provide the most compelling guidance for how to proceed. What separates religious believers from others is their lower preparedness to change/adapt to new information. Humans and other organisms are prone to habit forming because it is generally more efficient to automatically repeat established patterns of behavior than to effortfully select and replicate them, or invest energy in inventing new ones (Neal et al, 2006;Smith & Graybiel, 2016). This makes us susceptible to carrying forward pre-existing beliefs and behaviors when novel alternatives would be objectively superior. We may do so because we are not aware of alternatives or because we are not otherwise motivated to change. Both are encouraged by conservative values: lack of awareness being more likely if one's motivations oppose change-promoting, self-directed curiosity, and stimulation related adventurousness.

In accordance with law of accelerating returns, the rate of technological and scientific advancement was several orders of magnitude slower at the time when most of the world's major religions were first established. Therefore, the fitness-related costs of failing to adopt new ideas and practices in those times were relatively very small. Having taken hold, these beliefs and related practices serve purposes related to Maslow's belonging and safety needs. The conservative values of tradition, conformity, and security relate to these basic psychological needs.

They serve to bind people together in cooperative social groups. From the perspective of group members, new ideas and practices, and those propounding and practising them, may represent potentially destabilizing competition. This may encourage greater resources being devoted to protecting and reinforcing the boundaries and practices of their religions. This has the potential to isolate religious believers from outsiders, so facilitating intellectual stasis and increasing polarization of views with respect to differently and more progressively minded outsiders.

div.head: An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials)
div.p: As in all dynamically stable systems, the cooperative strategies that, in human terms, correspond with high-morality will tend to dominate in accordance with the evolutionary rationale described in the main paper in relation to the Prisoner's Dilemma. Competitive strategies can only be tolerated if they are subordinated to serve greater cooperative interests, or if the parasitism they promote is constrained so as not to catastrophically deplete the resources of the cooperative systems on which they prey. Consequently, as with a genetic predisposition for parasitism in certain organisms, the motivation for immoral behavior associated with the competitive values of power and achievement can be tolerated insofar as it does not catastrophically undermine the cooperative integrity of society or the functioning of an individual.

The other changes to the hierarchy proposed by Kenrick et al. (2010) involve the renaming of safety with self-protection, affection and belonging with affiliation, and the introduction of mate acquisition, mate retention, and parenting related needs above status/esteem related needs. The renaming is of little consequence but fails to address Maslow's misconception that safety (stability) is a function of cooperation (benevolence, including love), not the other way around. They justify the introduction of new needs with reference to life-history theory. This is not the place to conduct a review of this, nor attempt to contextualise the role of parenting within it. However, our observation would be that motives for mate-acquisition, mate-retention, and parenting are covered by the conservation half of the UMM, and so can be related to existing levels of need in Maslow's hierarchy. As described in the main paper, most sexually reproducing organisms rely on mechanisms related to the equivalent of power and achievement motivations to attract mates. These are rooted in genetic mechanisms that seek to maximise cooperative efficiency, albeit that these are susceptible to corruption (Miller, 2000). Mate retention (whether temporary or monogamous) represents a higher, more complex manifestation of the basic cooperation between two related genomes, but is not restricted to humanity, or even highly intelligent organisms (e.g., Mock & Fujioka, 1990;Whiteman & Côté, 2004). Yes, the considerable and extended investment of two parents in human offspring is related to the biological consequences of giving birth to and raising highly intelligent offspring that acquire much of the information they need to flourish from cultural interactions. And yes, this intelligence can be related to values at the top of our hierarchy, i.e., selfdirection, universalism, and benevolence (see SM3). However, in line with the trickle-down relationship we describe in the main paper, all evolutionary adaptations, genetic and cultural, have the potential to become rooted in motivations related to values (or their equivalents) at the base of the hierarchy, i.e., tradition and conformity. Given that co-parenting is a cooperative act, it would seem reasonable to anticipate that individuals motivated most by cooperative values at both ends of the hierarchy of values would be the most likely to commit fully to it, and those motivated by competitive values the least. Also, in terms of the quality of parenting they provide, it would seem reasonable to anticipate that parenting styles consistent with transformational leadership qualities (see Zacharatos et al., 2000) would have advantages over styles more consistent with transactional leadership. The former leaning more heavily on encouraging independence and creativity through support and challenge (associated with the self-actualizing values of self-direction, universalism, and benevolence); the latter more on command and control, extrinsic reward, and punishment (strategies more aligned with the self-enhancing values of power and achievement). values model concerns the motivations of individuals. Schwartz (2004) primarily to the power value. The final dimension of harmony-mastery is described in terms of an opposition between universalism values and mainly achievement values. However, harmony is described as a cultural tendency for fitting into the world rather than changing it, and therefore appears to blend universalism and conservative values.

div.head: Cultural and Organizational Values
div.p: One description used to measure universalism in the PVQ-40 (Schwartz et al., 2001) is worded as follows: 'It is important to them/him/her to adapt to nature and to fit into it. They/he/she believe that people should not change nature'. In our consideration, this is problematic in the context of universalism being a description of motivations for being sympathetic to others, open to the opinions of others, and desirous of accumulating knowledge toward a more complete understanding of people and nature. Scientific progress is reliant on better understanding nature and using what we learn to improve the lives of individuals and society. For example, while genetic engineering and nuclear power may be regarded as interfering with nature, they are replications of naturally occurring processes (Mervine, 2011;Shapiro, 1992). One can argue that all technological and scientific progress is reliant on the identification, understanding, and replication of natural mechanisms. While it is suggested the wheel is one of a few uniquely human inventions (Gambino, 2009), given there are naturally occurring cylindrical objects that roll, such as tree trunks and the stems of plants, and wheels are simply cylinders with comparatively small third dimensions, the invention of the wheel is perhaps an achievement equivalent to Columbus's 'discovery' of the Americas. Therefore, we are of the view that associating universalism with an antipathy to change is inappropriate.

In the context of the PVQ-40, it is possible to interpret the aforementioned descriptive statement as not being obstructive of progress. If one takes the view that all technology changes nature, the statement may appear so extremely demanding that it is better interpreted differently. If one takes the view that it is impossible to change nature, because all human inventions simply exploit what nature has to offer, then the statement similarly requires an alternative interpretation. A possible interpretation would be to consider the proposition as a means to measure how much the respondent cares for the natural world. However, Schwartz's more conservative cultural interpretation of harmony leans heavily toward a radically conservative interpretation.

As it happens, this is not the only problem with this interpretation of universalism. Another statement used to measure the importance of universalism is "They/he/she want everyone to be treated justly, even people they don't know. It is important to them to protect the weak in society."

To agree with these statements and to believe that people should not change nature requires the respondent to believe humanity's capacities for treating others unjustly and exploiting the weak are unnatural. Given that nature (including that relating to humanity) is, as Tennyson poetically An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials) observed, 'red in tooth and claw', it is difficult to claim a desire to exploit the weak, rather than protect them, is unnatural. If it is natural, then it would follow that it would be inconsistent with universalism to seek to change this. This inconsistency may not be problematic if respondents don't think too deeply about the implications of the statements. They may simply recognize broad themes that enable them to interpret the statements as being aligned with allegiances for environmentalism and social justice.

While Schwartz's cultural orientations are broadly aligned with his system of personal values, any ambiguity in translation is problematic. This may have contributed to correspondence between the two constructs falling short of isomorphism (Fischer et al., 2010). Given the apparent universality of the structure of the UMM, it is arguable that Schwartz's cultural orientations would be better reconsidered and mapped in relation to the UMM's orthogonal axes.

The cultural model used in the World Values Survey ( fig. 6 in the main paper) is that of Inglehart-Welzel (WVS, 2020), which maps survival values versus self-expression values on the x-axis and traditional values versus secular-rational values on the y-axis. As stated in the main paper, survival and traditional values correspond with Schwartz's conservation values, and self-expression and secular-rational values with self-direction and universalism . Accordingly, diagonal movement across the map is equivalent to vertical movement up our hierarchy from conservation values to self-transcending values.

div.head: Hofstede's (1980) cultural dimensions theory describes cultural values in terms of six dimensions:
div.p: power distance, individualism-collectivism, masculinity-femininity, uncertainty avoidance, longterm-short-term, and indulgence-restraint. Kaasa (2021) was able to demonstrate how these cultural dimensions could be merged with Schwartz's (2004) orientations. Power distance is like Schwartz's hierarchy-egalitarianism, and so maps with equivalents of power-universalism in value equivalents to the UMM, individualism-collectivism correlates strongly with embeddedness-autonomy Dobewall & Strack, 2014) The extent to which these different cultural models yield results aligned with expectations raised by our evolutionary theory can currently only be estimated by indirect comparison through Schwartz's personal values. Ambiguity in interpretation, of the type discussed in relation to universalism, and failure to make allowance for the inevitable complexities of measuring the culture of CAS comprising millions of individuals (each of which is a CAS) present considerable difficulties for those seeking confirmation of the coverage we suggest. However, given the impossibility of escaping (or defying being mapped on) the UMM, the UMM must also provide a parsimonious model for mapping cultural values, however they are described.

div.head: Personality Traits: The Big Five and HEXACO, The Big Two, and the Big One
div.p: It is said that traits describe what people are like, while values describe what people want from life (e.g., Parks-Leduc, et al., 2015). Vecchione et al. (2019, p.414) relate the five key differences between them identified by Roccas, et al. (2002) Fig. SM4 NEO-PI-R Five Factor Model (Costa & McCrae, 1992) of Big Five dimensions and facets supplemented by HEXACO (Ashton, et al, 2004) dimension of honesty/humility Big Five and HEXACO traits relate to behavioral characteristics: either directly, when the trait is immediately observable, or indirectly, when evaluated or inferred from observed patterns of behavior (e.g., Borkenau & Bielefeld, 1995 McCrae & Costa, (1999) contend the Big Five traits represent a set of basic tendencies with biological bases upon which dynamic processes give rise to characteristic adaptations, such as (they contend)

values, through interactions with the external environment. Such a perspective is consistent with traits being partially heritable (e.g., Plomin, 2018), broadly stable (Terracciano, et al, 2010), subject to change as people grow older (Roberts, et al., 2006), and responsive to the environmental effects of life events such as leaving the parental home or the death of a spouse (Specht, at al, 2011).

Values, like traits, are relatively stable (see review in , but may change as an individual's needs, physical state, or environment changes (e.g., Bardi et al, 2014;). For example, as people grow older, openness to change values tend to become less important and conservation values more important (Gouveia, et al., 2015). Life-events as varied as being exposed to war (Daniel et al., 2013) or going to university (Bardi et al., 2014) also affect values.

Rather than simply being characteristic adaptations of underlying traits, shaped by environmental interactions, as suggested by McCrae and Costa (1999), values, like traits, have been found to be heritable (Twito & Knafo-Noam, 2020;Zacharopoulos et al., 2016) and to share a common genetic root with traits (Schermer et al., 2011).

div.head: Known Relationships Between Traits and Values
div.p: There are systematic correlations between values and all trait dimensions apart from neuroticism (Parks-Leduc, et al. 2015). These are mirrored in similar terminology: e.g., curiosity, excitementseeking, self-discipline, and achievement-striving (traits), and curiosity, excitement, self-discipline, and achievement (values).

According to McCrae and Costa (1999), individuals are predisposed to exhibit traits such as curiosity and self-discipline without necessarily considering the corresponding values important. However, individuals tend to exhibit behaviour consistent with their most important values (e.g., Bardi & Schwartz, 2003;Skimina et al., 2018). found that values did not predict traits, but high levels of agreeableness and openness exerted an influence over the development of benevolence and self-direction respectively. However, in a previous study, found the values of children more predictive of behavior than traits were of values; albeit that a reciprocal relationship between the two seemed to be operating.

As acknowledged by , the interaction of personality traits and values is complex. There are 30 facets underlying the Big Five traits of NEO-PI-R (Costa & McCrae, 1992) , whereas traits are partially correlated and partially orthogonal (De Young et al., 2002). The frequency and intensity with which all traits are expressed, and the relative importance attached to each value may be infinitely variable. While some genes affecting personality seem to have been identified (e.g., Sanchez-Roige, et al., 2018), exactly how genes inform traits or values remains a mystery. Without the ability to identify and measure the genetic, physiological, and neurological processes underlying them, the challenges presented to those seeking to understand how each contributes to personality are considerable.

Personality has been described as 'the dynamic organization within the individual of the psychobiological systems that modulate … adaptations to a changing internal and external environment' (Cloninger, 2004, p.374). It is invoked to describe consistent differences in behaviour between all animals (Wolf & Weissing, 2012), even single celled bacteria (AMOLF, 2017;. It is apparent that personality is inferred when categorically similar individuals consistently behave differently in the same environment, suggesting the presence of hidden internal mechanisms or motivations. For example, the bacteria investigated by had identical DNA yet behaved differently in the same environment due to differences in their protein network (i.e., in the physical connections between cellular proteins).

The hidden mechanisms of human personality include thoughts and feelings, which may be expressed through actions, statements, and facial and bodily movements (e.g., Doherty, 2008). In common with all other organisms, such behavioral traits mediate the interaction of individuals with their environment (Sih et al., 2011) toward meeting their needs (McEwen & Wingfield, 2003). Given continual environmental change, it might be expected that characteristic patterns of behavior will change too.

However, individuals are inclined toward avoiding environments unsuited to their needs and values as well as being attracted to those to which they are better suited (Schwartz, 2012 (see SM3) would score higher on neuroticism than those belonging to other types. Digman (1997) suggested the Big Five traits could be further grouped into the 'alpha' and 'beta'

factors of social desirability/communion and growth-restriction/agency respectively. It is apparent these factors have at least some superficial similarity with the cooperation/competition and conservation/change axes of the UMM/Schwartz system. However, the lack of orthogonality between the Big Five traits (Block, 2010) In relation to the single general factor of personality (GFP) proposed by Musek (2007), Block considered ego-resiliency (ER) to be a personality catch-all that encapsulates social-effectiveness and emotional intelligence. In their summary of research into ER, Farkas and Orosz (2015) describe ER as encompassing traits orientated toward flexibility, resiliency, and general resourcefulness in a variety of changing situations. Ego-resilient individuals tend to be being more intelligent, resourceful, and adaptive than others, finding positive meaning in addressing problems, less likely to be orientated toward self-enhancement, and more able to delay gratification (Farkas & Orosz, 2015). These attributes suggest broad alignment between degrees of ER and the anticipated characteristics of An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials) individuals belonging to the four hierarchical motivational types described in SM3. In the case of intelligence and delayed gratification, our research findings already support this (see SM3, .

Research into the relationships between traits and values will doubtless reveal more information concerning their interaction. However, that human values are in themselves a CAS, existing within the CAS of the human brain, within the CAS of the individual, within the CAS of family and social groupings, within the CAS of humanity, that is itself part of the CAS of the global ecosystem, the challenge of controlling for or isolating all genetic and environmental effects is daunting.

div.head: A few examples of prominent evolutionary theories and perspectives
div.p: Carol Dweck (2017, p. 690) lays the foundations for a unified theory of motivation, personality, and development with the following: "I start with the assumption that psychological needs drive goals that support psychological life and health in much the way that physical needs drive goals that support physical life and health". Citing Baumeister and Leary (1995) she adds "to qualify as a basic need, it cannot be derivative of other needs". While the first statement may be true, to 'start' a theory that seeks to unify motivation, personality and development with an assumption that can only relate to organisms with brains sufficiently complex to warrant consideration in terms of psychology seems strange given, as we have argued, they have much deeper roots. If the second statement is correct, no psychological need can be considered 'basic' because, as our account of evolving complexity shows, psychological needs are derived from more fundamental physiological needs, and all of these are ultimately derived from the universe's 'need' to maximise entropy and minimize the total potential energy of its sub-systems. Considered in this light, all theories strictly bounded by the evolutionary history of our closest animal relatives, let alone those focusing only on homo sapiens, leave themselves open to criticisms of parochialism.

Having allowed that any psychological need could be considered basic, Dweck (2017) identifies three basic psychological needs: acceptance, optimal predictability, and competence, that are present An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials) from birth. From these emerge four compound needs of trust, control, self-esteem/status, and selfcoherence.

Dweck's (2017) basic need for acceptance can be derived from the UMM's cooperation/conservation quadrant and Schwartz's conformity values. Competitive/self-enhancing values (and their equivalents) may then build upon, exploit, and subvert this. Power and achievement values promote the demonstration of qualities that promote acceptance (and by extension, trustworthiness and group membership) and the influence this buys, whether honestly or by deception.

In evolving CAS, such as organisms, optimal predictability derives from cooperative, equilibriumseeking mechanisms that have evolved and operate similarly to problem-solving genetic algorithm. These facilitate the evolution of ever more sensitive pattern recognizing adaptations that enable organisms to synchronize behavioral change in response to early signs of change in their environment.

Dweck distinguishes competence from prediction by saying prediction concerns understanding whereas competence concerns action. Ultimately both share the same root in cooperation, which provides the foundation of stability that subordinate, dynamic competitive strategies supplement. In evolutionary terms, prediction and competence are co-dependent: the understanding that facilitates prediction only serves an evolutionary purpose if it enables improved courses of action. There could be no selection pressure on genes for understanding if such understanding could not find expression through action. The authors of Moral Foundations Theory (MFT; Graham et al., 2013) preface their proposition by quoting Einstein (1934, p. 165) -"The supreme goal of all theory is to make the irreducible basic elements as simple and as few as possible without having to surrender the adequate representation of a single datum of experience" -before identifying care-harm, fairness-cheating, loyalty-betrayal, authority-subversion, and sanctity-degradation as five fundamental dimensions of morality.
However, one barely need step outside the realm of psychology before these constructs are seen to lack parsimony.
MFT's care-harm, fairness-cheating, and loyalty-betrayal dimensions all transparently relate to the UMM's cooperative-competitive axis and Schwartz's self-transcendence-self-enhancement axes.

Authority-subversion may be considered from different perspectives, prompting different valuesrelated considerations. Insofar as authority concerns status, influence, and control, it is directly related to competitive power values. However, as previously described, these may all be more efficiently achieved in dynamic environments through higher values. Subversion involves one individual/group/system competing with another, either by direct action or through ideas and arguments. As such, it may arise from competitive power-related motivations. However, subversion may also arise involuntarily from progressive hedonism and stimulation values, or voluntarily through self-direction, supported by universalism. In a tightly regulated environment, the expression of desires to have fun and be adventurous may be perceived as wilful acts of subversion. However, when such non-conformist behavior subverts norms and defies authority, these may be considered An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials)
by-products of a motivation for self-expression more than a purposeful assault on authority.

However, when a self-directed motivation for independent thought and action (informed by universalism's drive for understanding) leads to a conflict with authority -whether it's the perceived authority of an argument, received wisdom, or an individual, group, or larger system -while any resultant action will be competitive, the ultimate motivation relates to a desire for greater cooperation: explanations and strategies that make better sense, promote more efficient actions, and lead to greater cooperative benefits. Sanctity-degradation again relates to the cooperationcompetition axis of the UMM. Sanctity promotes stability-enhancing cooperation through ideas and/or behaviors being given a protected status. This is the desired function of traditional customs and security related rules and boundaries. In dynamic environments, such fixed attitudes are likely to promote conflict between groups and cultures, irrespective of their intended purpose of promoting localised cooperation. Any idea or behavior that conflicts with those held to be sacred threatens their degradation, and so is likely to prompt defensive or aggressive action.

Rather than review further theoretical perspectives within psychology, since those we are aware of seem to share a common limitation, we will conclude this section with a more generalized commentary on studies in evolutionary psychology. According to Kurzban (2007;Scholarpedia, 2023) "evolutionary psychology begins with the idea that the source of organized functional complexity observed in all living organisms is evolution by natural selection. In its application to psychology, it entails the further uncontroversial assumption that the brain causes behavior.

Researchers in the discipline generally assume the basic principles of evolution by natural selection as articulated by Darwin (1859) and subsequent important developments, such as sexual selection (Darwin, 1871), the modern synthesis (e.g., Fisher, 1930) and inclusive fitness theory (Hamilton, 1964). They also tend to assume some form of the computational theory of mind (e.g., Fodor, 1975):

that what the brain does is process information (Pinker 1997)." It acknowledges the brain responds to external and internal inputs, evolving to become a problem-solving device, with specialized An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials) components attuned to solving ancestral problems, most of which operate unconsciously (Cosmides & Tooby, 1997).

A tendency for psychological theories to be developed as if humans were fundamentally different from other animals has been noted by others (e.g., Jonason and Dane, 2014). Jonason (2017) describes evolutionary psychology as a field of study that attempts to remedy this misconception.

However, our principal criticism of evolutionary psychology (as it most often presented) is that the context for considering the ancestral problems the brain evolved to solve is provided by savannadwelling homo-sapiens of a few hundred thousand years ago. While parallels are drawn and lessons learned through comparisons with other animals, this is the equivalent of trying to understand a story from its closing passages. The universe has been evolving for approximately 13.8 billion years in accordance with the same fundamental principles. If the story of evolution took 24 hours to read, and reading began at midnight, homo sapiens wouldn't come into it until less than two seconds before the following midnight. If, instead of starting at the beginning of the universe, we had 24

hours to read the story from when life first emerged on Earth, homo sapiens would be introduced at around 7 seconds to midnight. If we started with the emergence of multi-cellular life, we would still have only around 12 seconds to review the awe-inspiring complexity of homo sapiens and consider what makes us tick.

Concentrating on this small period of evolution has yielded many interesting findings. However, just as archaeology has revealed much that allows us to trace the evolution of human culture yet offers us little concerning the fundamental mechanisms responsible for it, in our opinion, evolutionary psychology has been too limited in its frame of reference to afford us a comprehensive view of the bigger picture. Our aim has been to frame our evolutionary theory of values in the broadest context possible. In finding congruence between the structure of the UMM and Schwartz's (1992) system we have been able to contextualise humanity's psychological evolution in relation to the laws of physics and the localised oscillating patterns of order and disorder that emerge in a universe seeking to maximize entropy. In so doing we have offered a means to better contextualize the detailed findings An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials)

emerging from specialised fields within psychology. The use of functional equivalents to Schwartz's values affords us relatable points of access through which we might gain a better understanding of the evolution of humanity and its many component and derived systems.

div.head: SM3 Method, Results and Discussion of Griffiths, Thomas, & Dyer (2022)
div.p: Amended and numbered to fit with these supplementary materials. This research into the influence of values on decision-making biases was not pre-registered. However, the rationale for researching the linear effects anticipated were previously set out by Griffiths (2013).

div.head: SM3 (a) (i) Procedure
div.p: Approval was granted by the ethical committees of Royal Holloway University of London (Phases 1 & 2) and Bournemouth University (Phase 3). Through a combination of personal invitations sent to organizations and advertisements placed on psychological research platforms (Psychological Research on the Net and Social Psychology Network) and at Bournemouth University psychology department, participants were recruited to complete online questionnaires in which they were presented with a values-related questionnaire followed by a series of decision-making challenges.

No financial inducements were involved. Some participating students received psychology course credits and all participants were offered a free personal values profile based on their responses accompanied by interpretative guidance notes.

Data was collected in three phases from 2014 to 2021. The same values questions were presented in all cases, but the decision-making challenges were modified between phases. From 1588 responses, after the pre-planned removal of data from: (1) 116 individuals declaring that English was neither their first language nor a language in which they had acquired naturalized proficiency, to a previous values question for a total of 12 times or more, including a sequential run of 5 or more. 9 , a total of 1317 individual responses remained to be analysed. 10

div.head: SM3 (a) (ii) Participants
div.p: Phase 1 involved 189 professional employees of commercial and not for profit organizations with an age range from 22 to 67 11 ). Of these 551 were North American, 156 were British, 50 were Asian, and the remainder were Other European, Australasian, African, and Other. The educational levels of participants were not recorded but professional participants were mostly educated to degree level, and most of those responding to the advertisements of psychological research platforms gave email addresses that suggested they were involved in higher education.

div.head: SM3 (a) (iii) Materials
div.p: Values data was collected with a 40-item, gender neutral, multiple-choice Schwartz Portrait Values Inventory questionnaire (PVQ-40;Schwartz et al., 2001) in which participants were asked to state the degree to which they associated themselves with the types of people being described (e.g.,
"They like surprises. It is important to them to have an exciting life") on a Likert scale (1 = not at all like me; 6 = very much like me).

The decision-making challenges presented in the various phases were as follows: to make an immediate decision on which one to use. They have the following curative properties: Medicine A will cure 30% of those infected; Medicine B has a 45% likelihood of curing all those infected and a 55% likelihood of curing none of those infected. Assuming these percentages are accurate, which do you choose? (all phases) Q4. 12 You are faced with making the following choices together.
a. Firstly, choose between being given: £240 for certain, or a 25% chance to gain £1,000 and a 75% chance of gaining nothing?

b. and then, taking a £750 loss for certain, or a £25% chance to lose nothing and a 75% of losing £1,000? (all phases) Q5. 12 If it takes 10 combine harvesters 10 minutes to harvest 10 hectares of wheat, how long would it take 20 combine harvesters to harvest 20 hectares? Options: Q7. Fluid intelligence. Participants were sequentially presented with a maximum of ten puzzles (see Fig. SM1-including eight Raven's Progression Matrices (RPM) ) to be completed within a timer-controlled ten-minute window. (Phase 1) Q8.
GAUT (Guilford, 1967) -"How many uses can you think of for an empty plastic lemonade bottle?" To be completed in a timer-controlled in two-minute window. (Phase 1)

Except for Q6(i) and Q8, participants had to choose between two and six options. Q7 was primarily intended to investigate values-related biases in fluid intelligence, but also to control for the influence of intelligence on answering the other decision-making challenges. Q7 was removed after Phase 1 to reduce the time demands on potential participants and thereby encourage greater participation, as were Q1, Q5 and Q8. Q1 and Q5 were reintroduced in Phase 3: Q1 in an amended form intended to elicit a greater variance in responses. In Phase 3, a different Bayesian inference 13 Adapted from Paulos (1988) challenge replaced the previous version -the aim being to improve the percentage of correct answers.

div.head: SM3 (a) (iv) Analysis
div.p: The average score of PVQ-40 responses relevant to each of the ten values was calculated for each respondent. These were used to calculate basic Pearson's correlations with respect to the decisionmaking challenges. These base figures were attenuated to compensate for the low internal reliability of values -a consequence of their being part of a continuum -by dividing them by the square root of Cronbach α figure for each value 14 (Spearman, 1904).

Given it is the relative importance of an individual's values within their motivational system that To better investigate the systematic influence of values, in accordance with Fischer's (2013, p. 1123) assertion that "what is important is the alignment with theoretically derived correlation patterns and such an alignment can be achieved independent of absolute correlation strength", we subjected value/performance correlations to shape-consistency analysis. Anticipating that values may exert influences consistent with the circular relationships described by the Schwartz system, and a linear hierarchical relationship sympathetic with the EToV, we used Procrustes analysis to find the greatest correlation between theoretically idealised transformations of sinusoidal (circular transformed to linear) shapes. This involved manually altering the phase, amplitude, and tilt of the sinusoidal axis of a single cycle of a sine wave to correspond with a single cycle of circle for each of the value/response correlation patterns (as depicted in figs.SM6-SM13 15 ).

As per Boer and Fischer (2013), correlations between an idealised waveform and experimental findings were calculated with respect to differences in the sum of the squares of two sets of ten yvalues corresponding to ten evenly distributed x-values corresponding to each of personal values (as they appear in fig.5). While such a distribution of values is sometimes depicted (e.g., Lee et al. 2019), it does not accurately reflect the relationships between values (e.g., Schwartz & Boehnke, 2004). While the general relationship between values and the two axes shown in fig.1 (main paper) is well established and broadly stable, the precise location of boundaries between values varies between studies . Rather than attempt to more accurately reflect this, in interpreting the results we adopted Boer and Fischer's (2013) To investigate the effects of systematic relationships between values more directly, we also analysed the decision-making of differently motivated individuals. In the absence of either a widely accepted methodology or typology that fits with an evolutionary, quasi-Maslowian interpretation of Schwartz's system, we adapted that of Dominant Needs Analysis (DNA) 16 . This allocates individuals to one of five motivational types, dependent on which is the central value of their dominant (i.e., most important) triad of neighbouring values (as illustrated in fig.SM5). Given the ten values are abstract divisions of a continuum, rather than being discrete , the use of higher order value triads is consistent with established theory and empirical precedent, such as when using the higher order values of self-transcendence, openness, self-enhancement, and conservation (e.g., Boer and Fischer, 2013). Three DNA motivational types fit the Maslowian hierarchy as illustrated in fig.SM2: the conservation values associated with love, belonging and security needs being most important to 'Shepherds'; self-enhancing values associated with esteem needs being most important to 'Hunters'; and self-actualizing/transcending needs and values to 'Philosophers'. A fourth hierarchical type, 'Explorers', located between Hunters and Philosophers as per the third proposed phase of evolutionary emergence, describes those for whom hedonism and stimulation are the most important.

div.head: Fig. SM5 Allocation of motivational types with respect to Schwartz's values
div.p: To generate personal values profiles amenable to analysis and cross referencing we followed instructions from Schwartz (2004). Standard scores were calculated for each value with reference to a norm group comprising 11,967 west Europeans from 12 western European nations, taken from the 2014 European Social Survey with an age range of 14 to 99 (M=43.1, SD=17.5). Standard scores were converted so that the lowest and highest could be represented within a 0-100% scale.
The average standard scores for values in each of the ten triads were calculated for each participant.

Individuals were initially allocated to one of the four hierarchical motivational types according to the location of the middle value of their highest scoring (i.e., dominant) triad (see fig.SM5). To better facilitate a linear, evolutionary, hierarchical, and Maslowian interpretation, individuals whose dominant triad was centered on benevolence were allocated to either the Shepherd type, if conformity was more important than self-direction, or the Philosopher type, if the reverse was true.

To evaluate the decision-making biases of individuals most likely to be subject to motivational conflicts, i.e., those for which no one triad, or wider set of sympathetic values, dominated others, a fifth motivational type labelled Moderators was used. All those whose dominant triad failed to outscore the next highest scoring and potentially conflicting triad by more than 6% were allocated to this type. Potentially conflicting triads were taken to be those with no common values. For this purpose alone, benevolence was treated as if it comprised two values: one associated more with tradition and conformity, the other with universalism and self-direction.

The choice of the 6% threshold was arbitrary but informed by a desire to set it high enough to Point biserial (Pearson) correlations between individuals' ten value scores and decisions were calculated for each of the decision-making challenges and Spearman (1904) adjustments for attenuation made. The relative performance of the motivational types was also analysed to provide Chi-Squared statistics for Q1 to Q7 and t-tests for Q8. The only significant correlation between any single value and responses was between stimulation and preparedness to wait in respect of Q1(ii), r(931) = .08, p = .018,. As shown in fig. SM6, different phase-shifted systematic sinusoidal patterns of value-response correlations were evident. In respect of Q1(i), 80-89% of all types preferred to wait a week for £5,600, rather than take £5,200 today (i.e., applied a discount rate of less than 371% pa), with no significant difference between the motivational types. All types were less willing to wait a month for the smaller reward of £5,500. chance of saving all over the certainty of saving 30%, N=1316. 95% confidence intervals shown. Fig. SM8 shows a tilted, highly shape-consistent, sinusoidal pattern of correlations between values and whether to invest a healthcare budget in a treatment that will save 30% of lives, or in one that has a 45% chance of saving everyone and a 55% chance of saving no one. Only those for selfdirection -r(1316) =-.06, p = .020 -and benevolence -r(1316) =-.07, p = .009 -were statistically significant. 50% of N=205 of Hunters and 48% of N=409 Explorers preferred a 45% chance of saving all, compared to just 38% of N=218 Philosophers: differences of  2 =4.80, 95% CI [0.20-0.01], p = .029, and  2 =4.52, 95% CI [0.17-0.01], p = .033, respectively.

As illustrated in fig. SM9, in respect of Q4(a) and a preparedness to risk a certain £240 gain for a 25% chance to gain £1,000, there were significant negative correlations for conformity: r(1313) =-.06, p =
