div.p: Values correlations and motivational type for performance in Q8: How many uses can you think of for an empty plastic lemonade bottle (in two minutes)? N=163. 95% confidence intervals
shown.

As shown in fig. SM13 the creativity of participants in their performance in Q8 yielded a strongly hierarchical, highly shape consistent pattern of correlations. Individual value correlations ranged from tradition: r(163) =-.18, p = .017 to benevolence: r(163) = .17, p = .024. This was broadly reflected in the average number of uses participants from each motivational type came up with.

Although the differences fell short of statistical significance, this is largely due to the small subsample of Shepherds (N = 10). The difference in the performance of Explorers and Shepherds was t(13) = 1.75, d = .59, p = .051, 95% CI [-0.12-4.11]. A post-hoc analysis of performance that controlled for performance in the first four puzzles in Q7 revealed only one significant partial correlation for self-direction: r(162) = .24, p = .002.
Shape consistency: r = .97, p < .001

div.head: Fig. SM14 Average values profiles of the 5 motivational types
div.p: An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials)

div.head: SM3 (c) Discussion
div.p: Consistent with previous findings (e.g., Bardi & Schwartz, 2003;Doran, 2009) this study revealed circular/sinusoidal patterns of values-related decision-making biases, but, consistent with theoretical expectations, these were supplemented by hierarchical influences. The patterns of personal risktaking between the motivational types was broadly in line with theoretical expectations, in that Shepherds were the most risk averse, Explorers the least, and Hunters ranking between the two in respects of Q1(ii), Q2 and Q4. For Q2 and Q4(a), the performance of the types followed the circle,

with Philosophers being similarly risk-averse to Hunters. However, in respect of Q4(b) Philosophers and Explorers were the least risk-averse, being as likely to risk incurring additional losses as not. This suggests an ambivalence consistent with our evolutionary justification of observations regarding the greater resourcefulness of self-actualizing individuals.

The expectation that Philosophers would be the most likely to give rationally supportable answers was met in respect of Q5, due to the significant positive contributions of self-direction and universalism. It is also possible to make a rational argument in support of their greater preference for guaranteeing the survival of 30% of the population in respect of Q3. This makes sense from a widely framed, self-transcending, tribal or genetic perspective, as it guarantees the survival of the tribe and its gene pool. The alternative -a 45% chance of saving all and a 55% chance of saving no one -only makes more sense from the perspective of a selfish individual, as it maximises the chances of personal survival yet is more likely to save no one.

The marginally superior performance of Philosophers and the significant hierarchical influence of values in Q7 is consistent with the expectation that Philosophers would display the highest intelligence and Shepherds the lowest. However, the relatively small sample involved, and the lack of statistically significant differences between the performance of the motivational types, limits what may be inferred from this result. The clearest evidence of a hierarchical pattern of influence was in respect of Q8, Guilford's (1967) Alternative Uses Test. The shape consistency of the pattern of An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials) value correlations and related motivational type performance suggest that statistically significant correlations and differences between the performance of the motivational types would be likely to emerge if the exercise was repeated with a larger sample.

Given that the independent thought and action associated with self-direction are inextricably linked with intelligence and creativity, that correlations between self-direction and success in Q7 and Q8

were lower than those for the neighbouring values of stimulation and universalism are puzzling. It may be that these arise from discrepancies between self-evaluation and reality, and from shortcomings in the way the systematic relationships between 'higher' and 'lower' values are accounted for. Evidence that such factors are at play would seem to be provided by the average Shepherd and Hunter profiles shown in fig. SM14. These show self-direction scoring higher than might have been expected given the trend of scoring in neighbouring values, suggesting a perceived influence at odds with the relative importance given to conformity and security.

Theoretical expectations concerning the greater potential for those most likely to be subject to values conflicts (i.e., Moderators) to respond rationally to propositions that invite erroneous intuitive responses, or involve delayed gratification, also seem to have been met. Because values exhibiting the greatest positive and negative correlations with responses to the various propositions were likely to be relatively less influential in the motivational systems of Moderators than they were to other types, one might have anticipated Moderators would perform close to the average of other types. However, Moderators most preferred the risky option with the higher equivalent value in Q4(a) and were among the most likely to wait a month for £5,500 rather than take £5,200 immediately in Q1(ii). Most striking was their superior performance in respect of Q6(i), where
Moderators provided more correct answers than all other types combined, despite only representing 17% of the sub-sample responding to this question.
It is apparent the changes made to the Bayesian challenges of Q6, including replacing an open response with a multiple choice, improved the success rate for all types. However, given a 33%

An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials) chance of guessing correctly in Q6(ii), that there were no significant differences between the type and only Hunters achieved an average success rate (34%) above this, the replacement of open responses with multiple choices seemingly made respondents of all types equally likely to disengage from rational consideration of the proposition.

Evidence for the influence of values on non-values-laden decision-making was found both in individual value scores and in the responses of differently motivated individuals. By accounting for the systemic interaction of values in individual motivational systems we found that relatively small, often statistically insignificant correlations between individual value scores and decisions concealed stronger, apparently values-driven influences. For example, over twice as many Explorers were prepared to risk losing £100 for a 50% chance of gaining £200 in Q2 as conservative Shepherds, despite no more than around 4% of the variation in choices being attributable to any one value.

Similarly, in respect of Q3, the apparently negligible contributions of self-direction and benevolence led Philosophers to be 28% more likely to prefer the certainty of saving 30% of people to a 45% chance of saving everyone than Hunters, who were most subject to the apparently negligible opposing influence of power and achievement.
As was demonstrated by changing considerations of delayed gratification in Q1, and the presentation of Q6, values-related responses may be highly sensitive to changing variables.

Inevitably, when the disparity between options becomes too small (or great) there will tend to be agreement between decision-makers regardless of their values. However, between these limits the influence of values can be expected to vary. If variance is normally distributed, it is to be expected that the different value priorities of individuals will contribute to the greatest divergence of decisionmaking somewhere in the middle. Future research might profitably explore decision-making challenges tuned to investigate 'sweet spots' of maximum values-related variance.
An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials)

div.head: SM3 (d) Strengths, limitations, and directions for future research
div.p: Our findings illustrate how values influence decision-making in relation to challenges designed to test system 1 (Stanovich & West, 2000) intuitive biases (Kahneman, 2011), and propensities for engaging system 2, rational thought (Kahneman, 2011;Stanovich & West, 2000). They also point toward how values affect rational capabilities. As such they advance our understanding of how values affect decision-making in real life. Kahneman (2011) suggested that the type of risk-aversion exhibited in response to equivalents of Q2 could give rise to considerable opportunity costs if replicated in the decisions of many individuals in many organizations. Over many iterations, as might happen in large organizations, preferences for 'safe' options with equivalent financial values considerably below those of 'risky' options would eventually become the equivalent of refusing gifts with real values equal to the differences in these equivalent values (£50 in Q2). However, the questions we presented are perhaps too simplistic to fully explore real-life decision making. Organizational decision-makers are also subject to prescriptive guidelines and cultural pressures (e.g., Jabs, 2005;Weber et al., 2005) likely to be as influential as their personal values and other personal biases. For individuals, comparable decisions are likely to made in the light of other considerations salient to values, such as previous experiences, their impact on others, and how they will be viewed by others.

As with any self-reporting measure, the accuracy with which responses to the questionnaire reflect the 'real values' of participants is uncertain. While removing data from some participants may have helped, it is likely spurious entries remained. Even genuine responses may be subject to imperfections in self-knowledge. The systematic nature of values enables us to review the likely influence of any one value with respect to others, which ascribing individuals to motivational types sought to do. However, as the suggested restrictions on the effective self-directedness of those who attach great importance to conservative and self-enhancing values illustrates, a reliance on self-assessed value scores to determine motivational type is likely to An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials) be sub-optimal. Allocational accuracy is most likely to be compromised when the margin by which values on the progressive half of the circle outscore those on the conservative half is small, because this may underestimate the restrictive influence of the 'lower' values. Given that the independent thought and action associated with self-direction are inextricably linked with intelligence and creativity, it seems likely the comparatively small correlations between self-direction and success in Q7 and Q8 relative to those for the neighbouring values of stimulation and universalism reflect such shortcomings in measurement. Budgetary constraints and a desire to make participation easier, and so expedite the gathering of data within time constraints, limited our ability to compare the relationship between intelligence, values, and decision-making. Research to analyse the performance of much larger samples with respect to a variety of measures of intelligence would shed further light on the apparent hierarchical relationship between values and intelligence, and their distinctive influences.

div.head: SM3 (e) Research Conclusion
div.p: Our findings suggest that values may play a more extensive role in decision-making than previously thought. In addition to the circular pattern of correlations between values and decision-making biases usually associated with the Schwartz (1992) system, there is evidence to suggest coexistent linear correlations consistent with our proposed evolutionary hierarchy. This superimposes developmental influences attributable to the evolution of the increasingly complex systems of humanity: from the simple conservation of energy in its most fundamental components and antecedents, to the intelligent self-regulation of the CAS it has become. Additionally, the evidence suggesting individuals most likely to be prone to experiencing values conflicts are more likely to make decisions that fit neither with circular nor linear hierarchical patterns of correlations, and points toward values playing an important role in mediating between systems 1 and 2 thinking (Stanovich & West, 2000).

div.head: SM4
div.p: Implications and Applications

div.head: SM4 (a) Organizations & Government
div.p: According to the EToV, an evolutionary trend toward the increasing influence of the higher values should be ongoing. As the rate of innovation and technological progress increases in accordance with the law of accelerating returns , not only do people have more useful information at their disposal, but they have greater access to and means of sharing this with others.

In harmony with niche construction theory (Odling-Smee et al., 2003), this effectively creates cultural selection pressure on the higher progressive values that promote learning, creativity, and cooperation, which in turn feeds back into increasing the potential for innovation and technological advancement.

However, set against this trend are individuals, groups, and societies relatively more motivated by the conservation values. Consistent with social identity theory (Hogg, 2016;Korte, 2007), homophily (McPherson et al., 2001, and the sympathetic relationships between values explained by , one might anticipate that individuals will tend to feel more at ease with, and therefore preferentially seek out, others who share similar value priorities. This encourages localised convergence and harmonization. Such de-homogenizing has the broader systematic effect of accentuating divisions between the social identities of differently motivated groups. In conservative The systematic challenges presented by globalization, climate change, and the growth of technology that replaces many but is owned by a few (Freeman, 2015) are among those presenting themselves in an increasingly volatile, uncertain, complex, and ambiguous (VUCA) world (Mackey, 1992).

Meeting these with comprehensively informed initiatives requires ever greater numbers of individuals with a diversity of specialized and generalized knowledge to work cooperatively. Even within a scientific community reliant on shared information and learning, overcoming the boundaries between specializations that frustrate transdisciplinary cooperation seems to be proving problematic (Er Saw & Jiang, 2022).
An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials)

We perceive two major values-related issues to be inhibiting societies around the world from enabling the type of challenging cooperative endeavour required. Firstly, the value most directly associated with the status, influence, and control involved in leadership is power. Given the links between values, career choice, and organizational culture (Arieli et al., 2020), and between motivation and achievement (Johnson et al., 2014), it seems likely that those most likely to occupy positions of power in large organizations, whether educational, commercial, or governmental, are power-driven. Consistent with this expectation, research by Babiak et al. (2010) suggests that psychopathy, which is associated with power-related motivation (Glenn et al., 2017), is significantly more common in senior leaders than in the general population.

Power-driven individuals are motivated to behave in ways that facilitate others deferring to them and granting them the influence and control they desire. Power is a competitive value likely to inhibit cooperation. In increasingly complex and fast changing environments the less likely it becomes that any one individual has the knowledge to make effective decision-making without incorporating information from other sources. In such environments effective decision-making demands cooperation between individuals who are helpful, curious, open to the ideas of others,

willing and able to share information, able to admit mistakes, honest, forgiving, capable of developing broad based understanding, etc. These are all qualities associated with the higher values, which may in turn be associated with transformational leadership (Bass, 1985). These progressive and cooperative values are in opposition to the lower conservative values when considered hierarchically, and to the competitive values when considered in terms of circle.

Behaviors associated with conservative values, such as following instructions, fitting in, not challenging the status quo, tend to be well adapted to large organizations, as they promise to maximise efficiency by suppressing internal conflict and uncontrolled risk-taking. They are useful to power-driven leadership, as they encourage deference to those in positions of power. The challenge for large organizations is how to reconcile personal power-driven tendencies toward the pursuit of short-term goals with the self-transcending characteristics required for sustainable prosperity.
An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials)
Personal compulsions to raise and maintain one's status, influence, and control, frustrate cooperative working, innovation, and rational risk-taking.

The second and related problem is that, in progressive democracies, governments are elected by popular vote. The more volatile, uncertain, complex, and ambiguous the world becomes, and the greater the effects of cultural drag become, the larger the proportion of electorates unwilling or unable to engage with, let alone understand, the complex challenges arising is likely to become.

Given a choice between: (1) a power-driven potential leader that offers an electorate information it can comprehend, analyses of the problems they face that fit with their own prejudices, and seemingly simple solutions that promise not to adversely affect them; and (2) a self-actualizing, leader that honestly presents the nature of the complex challenges faced, and the perhaps uncomfortable changes people must make to overcome them, it would seem increasingly likely that electors will favor the former. From the perspective of natural selection, in these circumstances, power-driven leaders may exploit public ignorance to promote strategies that are better adapted to this psychological environment than alternatives better adapted to reality.

While these issues may present huge challenges, the knowledge that organizations led by transformational leaders (i.e., those likely to be motivated most by higher values) tend to perform better (e.g., García-Morales et al., 2012;, and be better places to work (e.g., Sun & Wang, 2016;Toor & Ofri, 2010), should make it possible to offer such leaders and organizations as exemplars. Also, since people's values can be developed (Bardi & Goodwin, 2011), the hierarchical structure we have identified, and the developmental logic that explains its evolution, would seem to offer considerable potential in identifying and pursuing initiatives in personal and organizational development to improve societal preparedness to address the challenges of the VUCA
world.
An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials)

div.head: SM4 (b) Mental Illness & well-being
div.p: Given the fundamental role we suggest values and their equivalents play, there would seem to be great potential to extend values-related research into other fields. Mental illness and well-being, for example, would seem to be areas ripe with potential. The strong positive correlation of power and negative correlation of benevolence with Dark Triad personality traits (Kajonius et al., 2015), and the latter's association with psychopathy (Paulhus & Williams, 2002), hints at the possibility of there being a common neurological driver for the imbalances involved.

Paulhaus & Williams (2002) observed that subclinical psychopaths were low on neuroticism. Given the intimate relationship between values and affect , and the reasonable conjecture that the affect heuristic influences all decision-making (Zajonc, 1980), those most prone to experiencing values conflicts seem most likely to experience mixed feelings that make decisionmaking difficult and potentially stressful. If so, those least prone to values conflicts would seem the least likely to experience emotional instability. In the case of psychopaths, the lack of a moderating influence from other values, particularly benevolence, might effectively grant power-related motivations free reign. While those otherwise strongly motivated by any dominant value or suite of values might also be expected to experience little in the way of motivational conflicts, the influence of other values may be sufficient to normalize their behavior within the bounds of social acceptability.

It is perhaps worth pointing out that such conflicts could be internal, due to opposing values being similarly dominant, or because an individual's dominant values conflict with the values-equivalents of their environment. Given that each value contributes to the motivational environment of the others, both situations would be consistent with an extended systematic interpretation of the person-environment fit approach analysed by van Vianen (2018); i.e., local system-wider system fit.

For example, an individual who places equal importance on self-direction and conformity might experience stress as they experience opposing urges to express their individuality through self-An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials) direction and their need to fit in through conformity. Similarly, an individual who is constrained, ostracised, or otherwise frustrated by lack of fit with others, because, say, of a conflict between personal self-directedness and group conformity, is likely to experience negative emotions (Leary, 2015;. Accordingly, further examination of the systematic relationship between values and values-equivalents in person-environment approaches, between values and emotional instability, and with other mental health issues may yield information that would aid understanding, prevention, and treatment.

One possibility we have considered, but for which we have no clear evidence, is that unrestrained self-direction may be linked to autism spectrum disorder (ASD) in ways comparable to the link between unrestrained power motivation and psychopathy. To be clear, the lack of restraint being referred to is speculated to arise from genetically rooted, UMM-related neurological mechanisms from which values emerge, rather than simply being related to values per se. The apparent link between self-direction and intelligence and the exceptional mathematical abilities of some individuals with ASD (e.g., Iuculano et al., 2014) draws one's attention. More common symptoms of ASD include: inabilities to read and express feelings and interpret information other than literally;

being blunt/rude; needing to maintain routine; picking up on detailed information that others miss; having an obsessive interest in certain subjects (NHS, 2023). Of these, the last two can be considered direct expressions of curiosity, which is a component of self-direction. The remainder may be considered deficiencies resulting from a lack of influence from other values. Social skills evolved to promote and exploit cooperation, and over time became culturally enshrined. As such, they are rooted in the conservation/cooperation quadrant of the UMM, and carried forward in the values of benevolence, tradition, conformity, and security. Abilities to recognise and exploit these for competitive advantage followed and can be associated with the change/cooperation quadrant of the UMM: carried forward in the personal values of power and achievement. Accordingly, it is tempting to consider the possibility that aspects of neural function associated with self-direction have developed at the expense of those associated with lower values.
An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials)

The need for routine associated with ASD could be matched to the value of conformity. However, an alternative interpretation is that a compulsion for curiosity and understanding is so great in ASD sufferers that they are prone to extreme stress from information overload. If so, maintaining routines in which there is a relative absence of new information, and comforting opportunities to explore familiar areas of information more thoroughly, may be seen as effective coping strategies.

Other areas of potential concerning motivational imbalances would appear to be addiction and bipolar disorder. The values of particular interest here would appear to be achievement, hedonism, stimulation, and self-direction. Superficial associations between values-related motivation and behavior suggest links between: achievement and being a workaholic; hedonism and addiction to sex, alcohol and/or drugs; and stimulation to risky, high-adrenaline activities, or, more generally, restlessness or attention deficit syndrome. Logically, if the need-satisfying behaviors these values promote fail to achieve homeostasis, the urge to maintain them will be maintained. Therefore, regardless of an individual's achievements, achievement-related desires to win the approval of others will not abate. Similarly, regardless of the hedonistic pleasure and novel activity promoted by hedonism and stimulation values, an individual will not arrive at a state of motivational equilibrium, and so will continue to indulge these values.

It is possible to consider the hierarchical evolutionary structure of values we propose as a developmental structure that may also be ascended in a lifetime. If needs associated with each value are satisfied, surplus resources may be freed up for investment in behaviors aimed at satisfying the next value up in the hierarchy. As described in the main paper, the logic being that each successive value offers a more efficient means of satisfying basic needs. Accordingly, as subsequent values are engaged, reliance on lower values may diminish. As with financial investments, the ability to make the type of higher-risk/higher-reward investments associated with the higher values is contingent on the availability of a surplus. Those unable to satisfy needs associated with lower values will be unable to free up resources to make these potentially more rewarding investments. They will find themselves in the emotional equivalent of a poverty trap.
An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials)

Given the heritability of values (Twito & Knafo-Noam, 2020;Zacharopoulos et al., 2016), it is likely we are born with predispositions that upset this developmental sequence. If the shuffling of genes in meiosis allows individual motivational systems with randomized value priorities, and varying linkages between values and behavior, an individual's ability to resolve motivational conflicts and develop through progressive phase transitions is likely to be frustrated. However, where genetic barriers to development are relatively low, the type of value-changing initiatives described by Bardi and Goodwin (2011) may overcome them.

We consider the possibility of a link between bi-polar disorder and malfunctioning homeostatic relationships between these values on the grounds that bi-polarity is associated with higher intelligence, risk-taking, alcohol and drug abuse, feelings of worthlessness and negative affect (e.g., Brady & Sonne, 1995;Green et al., 1993;Motovsky & Pecenak, 2013;Nowakowska-Domagała et al., 2023). These cited resources are consistent with personal observations of individuals suffering from bipolar disorder. A possible interpretation of a link between values and bipolar disorder is that, despite having strong self-directedness (which we relate to higher intelligence) and impressive track records of achievement, afflicted individuals are prone to feeling themselves to be worthless and hopeless failures, leading them to invest their surplus energy in hedonistic and thrill-seeking activities from which they derive no long-term satisfaction. It is easy to picture this in terms of a value system with similar features to that illustrated in fig. SM15, i.e., with similarly dominant achievement, hedonism, stimulation, and self-direction values.

div.head: SM4 (c) In a wider context
div.p: If, as we suggest, all systems can be considered as evolving in relation to the axes of the UMM, then it would follow that equivalents to Schwartz's values may useful in providing relatable strategies by which to consider their operation. This is perhaps of greatest interest when considering humanity's relationship with economic and ecological systems. As we have argued, sustainable evolution requires competitive strategies to be subservient to cooperative ones. Yet large organizations and governments tend to provide environments better adapted to those motivated by the competitive values of power and achievement. This perhaps has encouraged the promulgation of a mistaken belief that competition alone drives progress, and this rather than cooperation needs to be protected (e.g., see FTC, 2023). Given that progress is ultimately dependent on innovation, and innovation is facilitated by the cooperation of two or more previously disconnected ideas or pieces of information, research into which requires broad-based understanding and carries no guarantee of success, innovation is better facilitated by self-direction, universalism, and benevolence than power and achievement. The purpose of competition is to: judge the cooperative efficiency of two or more different strategies or products, eliminate the least effective, and preferentially distribute the most An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials) effective, so mimicking natural selection's survival of the fittest. Seen as such, competition may be considered as serving waste-management and replication functions more than driving innovation.

If the purpose of competition is misunderstood, so too is the potential for cooperation to be misunderstood. The values that promote self-transcendent cooperation are universalism and benevolence. Universalism concerns gaining knowledge of the natural system of which humanity is part. Because the natural world evolves through the interaction of competitive and cooperative strategies, universalism promotes not just an understanding of the virtues of cooperation, but also the role of competition. While the 'tit for tat' strategy of the Prisoner's Dilemma may be considered a broadly cooperative strategy, it dictates immediate retaliation against those failing to cooperate.

As discussed previously, the higher values offer alternative strategies to supplement those promoted by the lower values. They are not simply replacements for them. Consequently, a universalist and benevolent approach allows for a ruthlessness that might seem uncooperative when considered within narrow contexts. However, in wider contexts, ruthlessly targeting and destroying competitive strategies unaligned with overarching cooperative strategies sustains systemic cooperation in ways similar to treatments intended to destroy cancer cells in the human body.

Inconsistency in the treatment of competitively minded business and political leaders on one hand and competitively minded criminals and slackers on the other illustrates a misunderstanding of the role of competition. When populist leaders ruthlessly pursue strategies to undermine competitors in pursuit of personal or team gain they may be lauded as if they were sporting or military victors (Rhodes & Hart, 2014). However, when fraudsters, drug dealers, and benefit cheats employ comparable strategies they are more likely deemed scourges of society (e.g., Baker & McEnery, 2015;Berghoff & Spiekermann, 2013;Boddy et al., 2015). A better understanding of the relationship between cooperation and competition and the values that support them, and an increased representation of individuals with motivational systems dominated by cooperative values (i.e., those most likely to promote cooperative strategies) in corporate and political governance, would seem to offer widespread benefits for society. Indeed, if we are to make the progress required to avert An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials) environmental and political crises (Boin et al, 2016), and raise ourselves to confront the unfolding challenges presented by artificial intelligence, this would seem essential.

figure.figDesc: universal motivational map (UMM) resonant with the structure of

that lead to scientific breakthroughs, invention, and innovation are themselves cooperative acts (e.g., Beck et al., 2022). A phase transition comparable to that orchestrated by the combination of physical systems takes place when complementary pieces of information are brought together. The inspiration that provides the equivalent of activation energy may result from accident, curiosity, thought experiment, and/or pattern recognition. Patterns suggest where continuations might lead, or highlight aberrations or conflicts indicative of missing or misinterpreted information. With evolving knowledge came emergent phenomena such as written language, the printing press, and the Internet: each with the potential to further improve humanity's cooperative endeavour and operational efficiency. The evolution of the complex genetic system that facilitated humanity's superior processing capability (e.g., Plomin & Deary, 2015), may have been a gateway event (Morowitz, 1999) that gave our ancestors an enduring competitive advantage over other organisms. The more complex the interaction of genes, phenotypes, and environment required to facilitate superior processing, the less likely it would have been that selection pressure on random gene mutations in competing organisms would have given rise to combinations capable of facilitating effective counter measures. If this, the absence of intense competition from other hominins in a dispersing population (Huff et al. 2010), and our greater cooperative potential, cut the genome of our ancestors some slack from the competitive pressures of natural selection, potentially costly genetic mutations offering no immediate competitive advantage, that would otherwise have been eliminated, would more likely have been tolerated, passed on, and made available for future environmental testing.

Observing that the self-enhancement/self-transcendence dimension of the Schwartz system alone covered McClelland's (1961) 'Big Three' motivations of power, achievement, and intimacy, Bilsky (2006) went on to investigate its coverage of the wider range of motivations listed in the German Personality

figure.head: An
figure.figDesc: Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials) Our findings revealed both sinusoidal and linear hierarchical patterns of influence, as illustrated by the three sets of results shown in fig.6, adapted from Griffiths, Thomas & Dyer (2022) (this adaptation is reproduced more fully in the supplementary materials appended to this pre-print). The linear component (derived from Procrustes analysis) was most pronounced in respect of the RPM fluid intelligence and GAUT creativity tests shown in fig.6(a) & (b). While, in other tests, a hierarchical influence was subordinate to the sinusoidal pattern associated with the circular arrangement of values, it remained apparent, as shown in respect of the challenge referred to infig.6(c) that depicts value correlations with a preparedness to risk losing £1,000 for a 25% chance of losing nothing rather than accept a certain £750 loss. For this, the polar opposition in preparedness to accept risk associated with the circular arrangement of conservation and openness to change values is seen to exert the greatest influence. However, the linear hierarchical component is clear, and fits with our evolutionary theory, insofar as higher values and their equivalents are deemed to have evolved in sympathy with trends toward greater capacities for innovativeness and the accumulation of surplus personal resources: the creative experimentation required for innovation demanding a preparedness to invest resources without immediate prospect or guarantee of making a return.

uncertainty principle. This states that it is not possible (even in principle) to simultaneously ascertain their location and momentum precisely. Accordingly, they are never at rest. Even at the absolute zero temperature of -273 O C they are subject to quantum fluctuations(Taylor-Smith, 2019). This effectively means that the fundamental building blocks of nature (e.g., the hydrogen, carbon, oxygen, and nitrogen atoms that make up over 95% of the mass of a human, including the brain) are dynamic systems of microscopically unpredictable components.An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials) All matter comprises atoms of differently configured fundamental particles (quarks and electrons). Distinctive systematic configurations thereof define the 92 naturally occurring atomic elements. Combinations of differently charged quarks make up the neutrally charged neutrons and positively charged protons that comprise atomic nuclei. Protons and neutrons contribute almost all the mass to the elements. They are surrounded by clouds of negatively charged electrons, equal in number to protons in the nucleus. figure.head: Fig. SM2
figure.label: SM2
figure.figDesc: Comparison of hierarchy of needs and values If Maslow's 'safety' and 'love and belonging' needs are considered as one, their associated values correspond with Schwartz's conservation values and some benevolence values. While Maslow considered safety more fundamental than love and belonging, as a social species, the familial and tribal cooperation associated with the latter are fundamental to humanity's safe physiological existence (Boyd & Richerson, 2009). The values Maslow associated with his esteem needs correspond with the values of power and achievement, and his self-actualization/transcendence needs principally to self-direction, universalism, and the remaining benevolence values. The An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials) hedonism value of 'enjoying life' and the stimulation value of 'exciting life' loosely correspond with Maslow's self-actualizing values of playfulness and liveliness.

(see SM3), it is possible to meaningfully evaluate the motivational systems of An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials) individuals in accordance with our evolutionary framework and typology, while being sympathetic to Maslow's hierarchy.Renovating the pyramid of needs(Kenrick et al., 2010) Kenrick et al.(2010), in accepting the broad utility of Maslow's model, sought to update it to be sympathetic with their interpretation of empirical developments since Maslow's time. In doing so they address many of the challenges of understanding how different aspects of human motivation and behavior might have evolved.

Values directly and transparently relate to morality through benevolence values such as honesty and forgiveness. Through the systematic relationships between values, all other values are indirectly related to morality. The conservative values seek to perpetuate cooperation through setting formal moral codes, following the good example of respected others, and by punishing transgressors.Immorality finds expression in behavior deemed to be antagonistic to cooperation because it is selfish and/or damaging to others. While self-enhancement values are not inherently immoral, their opposition to self-transcendence values reflects the increased likelihood that competitive selfinterest will promote attitudes and behaviors prejudicial to the interests of others.Moral behavior might be considered as that which conforms to the maxim of the golden rule: do what you will but harm none. While perceptions of what is right, harmful, or moral may be subjective and dynamic (e.g.,Day et al., 2014), law-making seeks to promote morality through statute. Immoral behavior such as deceit, theft, wilful manipulation, physical attacks, and other forms of law-breaking are competitive acts that seek to benefit an individual at the expense of the cooperative interests of others. Moral behavior reflecting honesty, consideration for others, helpfulness, and bearing responsibility for one's actions are cooperative acts that seek to maximise shared group benefits.

figure.label: SM3
figure.figDesc: Schwartz's (2004) Cultural Orientations Embeddedness concerns group identification and collective striving toward shared goals, but with an emphasis on maintaining the status quo through predominantly conservative values. In Schwartz's system of personal values conservative values oppose the openness to change values of hedonism, stimulation, and self-direction. These values find expression in affective and intellectual autonomy orientations. Egalitarianism concerns cooperation based on a belief in moral equality through universalism and benevolence values. The opposing orientation of hierarchy is intended to describe cultures in which inequality is accepted as an inevitable consequence of power structures, related

and hence with conservation-openness to change, as An Evolutionary Theory ofValues (with supplementary materials) should uncertainty avoidance (conservation providing the certainty of continuity), and restraintindulgence (conservation values, by definition, promote restraint against change, while the openness to change value of hedonism is readily associated with self-indulgence). As illustrated with reference to the Prisoner's Dilemma in the main paper, long-termism and short-termism readily relate to cooperative and competitive strategies respectively. However, given that conservative values are the least progressive, one could argue they promote narrow-framed, short-term attitudes such that one might anticipate an evolutionary hierarchical dimension to the influence of values in relation to this dimension. Indeed, those most motivated by conservative values have been shown to be the least prepared to defer reward (see SM3,. The masculinity-femininity dimension associates stereotypical gender attributes such as assertiveness, strength, and competitiveness with masculinity, and nurturing, quality of life, and cooperation with femininity. As such, this dimension can be readily associated with the competition-cooperation dimension of the UMM.

as follows: "(a) traits are enduring dispositions, An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials) whereas values are enduring goals; (b) traits refer to dispositional proclivities to behave in certain ways, regardless of one's intentions, whereas values refer to the goals people wish to accomplish; (c) traits vary in the frequency and intensity of their occurrence, whereas values vary in their importance as guiding principles in people's lives; (d) values are regarded by the individual as something desirable, whereas traits are not necessarily seen as desirable; and (e) values are ordered by importance relative to one another and may express conflicting motivational goals, whereas traits do not form an ordered system of priorities and do not conflict with one another". The Big Five is the most widely accepted model of personality traits. Its five traits of neuroticism, extraversion, openness to experience, agreeableness, and consciousness each comprise six facets, to which the HEXACO model added the sixth dimension of honesty/humility with four facets, as shown in fig. SM4.

offers some explanation for why the pattern of correlations for the alpha traits of agreeableness, conscientiousness, and neuroticism, and for the beta traits of extraversion and intellect/openness, don't quite fit with expectations. De Young et al. (2002) prefer stability and plasticity as two overriding factors; a classification that clearly corresponds with the conservation/change values dimension.

figure.head: Dweck's compound
figure.figDesc: needs for trust, control, self-esteem/status, and self-coherence are similarly easy to associate with Schwartz's values and the UMM. Trust arises from benevolent cooperative relationships or sources of information that agree (cooperate) with that gained from experience and rational analysis. Conservative values seek to consolidate and protect this by limiting change, while competitive values are more likely to promote strategies that exploit trust for personal gain. Selfactualizing values promote trustworthiness through their promotion of gaining and disseminating An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials) reliable information. Control is directly related to power values but, in terms of sustainable control over one's direction of travel in dynamic environments, may be achieved more efficiently through the higher values. Similar applies to self-esteem and status: both directly related to power values, but ultimately better realized through self-actualizing values. Self-coherence largely corresponds with Maslow's self-actualization needs, and so to Schwartz's self-direction, universalism, and benevolence values. Accordingly, Dweck's model offers aspects of need that can be derived from the UMM's change and mode of change axes.

SM7, a pronounced sinusoidal pattern of correlations with medium shape consistency emerged in respect of Q2. The tilt of the sinusoidal axis was relatively small but consistent with lower values promoting risk aversion. The greatest negative correlations were for tradition and security: r(185) =-.18, p = .015, and r(185) =-.18, p = .013 respectively, and the greatest positive correlation was for universalism: r(185) = .15, p = .036. A sympathetic pattern of performance was observed in the motivational types, ranging from a mean of 2.6 correct answers (65% success) for Shepherds (N=10) to 3.0 correct answers (75% success) for Philosophers (N=45), in respect of the first four puzzles, exaggerated to 4.27 and 4.9 respectively over all ten puzzles, albeit the differences were not significant. While referencing a west European norm group enabled us to compare individual motivational systems relative to a consistent benchmark, the difficulties associated with accurately assessing the relative influences of values in individual motivational systems are likely to be compounded by variations in the way different individuals, groups, and cultures represent their values. It may be possible to improve upon the coarse-grained findings we have made with appropriate controls and refinements, but neurological investigation may be required to gain a fine-grained understanding of people's values and their influence on decision-making.It may be that values-related decision-making biases are more fully revealed in real life situations concerning propositions that are more ambiguous and complex, and in respect of which the consequences of decisions are real and the risks tangible. Indeed, given that organizations tend to foster cultures, and therefore nurture individuals, sympathetic to the value priorities of their leaders(e.g., Hoffmann, et al., 2011), and the effects of consistent decision-making biases seem likely to be exaggerated and compounded when the challenges people face are contingent on the outcome of previous decisions, there would seem considerable potential for relatively small biases to have considerable compound effects. Large scale longitudinal research that analyses the responses of different motivational types to a range of comparable challenges that satisfy these criteria, in a variety of domestic and organizational settings, would help in developing a better understanding.An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials)

cultures, lack of personal curiosity, restrictive beliefs, and localised societal initiatives such as excluding sections of the community from education, as the Taliban have done with females in Afghanistan (Ahmadi & Ebadi, 2022), or inhibiting the teaching of evolution by natural selection in certain US states (Worldpopulationreview.com, 2020), impose a cultural drag on the global dissemination of knowledge, further frustrating social integration. This increases the potential for destructive competition between progressive and conservative forces in the global systems of humanity.

environment, and then taking appropriate action requires complex interactions of capabilities,
especially when that environment is itself a CAS. Sensory awareness involves receptors capable of
detecting photons, vibrations, molecules, and texture. Making sense of this information requires
processing mechanisms capable of recognizing patterns in it (fundamental to intelligence) and

row.cell: An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials)

figure.figDesc: Openness to change values are unsurprisingly positively correlated with openness to experience traits, and, in accordance with the rationale previously set out in relation to religiosity, conservation values are negatively correlated. One might anticipate that self-enhancing (competitive) values would incline individuals toward exerting an influence, or making an impression on others, irrespective of the desires of those third parties. When compared to those less inclined to make an impression, such extraverted behavior is more likely to conflict with the desires of others.Consequently, the finding that self-enhancing values correlate positively with extraversion, and negatively with agreeableness fits with expectations. Reciprocally, that the opposite is true for selftranscending values is also fitting. Similarly, it is no surprise that the dutiful compliance one might associate with conscientiousness relates positively to conservation values (following precedent, being obedient, and observant of rules) and negatively to openness to change values. Given honesty is a component of benevolence, the positive and negative correlations between the honestyhumility dimension of HEXACO and self-transcending and self-enhancing values also matches expectations.An Evolutionary Theory of Values (with supplementary materials)Of the Big Five, only neuroticism (or emotional instability) fails to show meaningful correlations.Given that emotions are components of decision-making processes, and values are inextricably linked to affect, it would be reasonable to consider that those individuals most subject to values conflicts would likely score highly in neuroticism. When the values most important to an individual are sympathetic to each other (i.e., are located next to each other in the Schwartz system) they will tend to work together. However, in personal value systems where no sympathetic group of values dominates, competition between conflicting emotions seem likely to result in emotional instability. If so one would expect those individuals classified as belonging to the Moderator motivational type

known that people such as this witness can distinguish between Blutos and Rimini
with 90% accuracy in similar conditions. What is the likelihood the witness got it
right, and the criminal is a Rimini? Options: 10%, 50% or 90%. (Phase 3)
